      11. 11
        Ware, W.; Wright, T.; Mao, Y.; Han, S.; Guffie, J.; Danilov, E. O.; Rech, J.; You, W.; Luo, Z.; Gautam, B. Aggregation Controlled Charge Generation in Fullerene Based Bulk Heterojunction Polymer Solar Cells: Effect of Additive. Polymers 2021, 13, 115,  DOI: 10.3390/polym13010115
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11
        Aggregation controlled charge generation in fullerene based bulk heterojunction polymer solar cells: effect of additive
        Ware, Washat; Wright, Tia; Mao, Yimin; Han, Shubo; Guffie, Jessa; Danilov, Evgeny O.; Rech, Jeromy; You, Wei; Luo, Zhiping; Gautam, Bhoj
        Polymers (Basel, Switzerland) (2021), 13 (1), 115CODEN: POLYCK; ISSN:2073-4360. (MDPI AG)
        Optimization of charge generation in polymer blends is crucial for the fabrication of highly efficient polymer solar cells. While the impacts of the polymer chem. structure, energy alignment, and interface on charge generation have been well studied, not much is known about the impact of polymer aggregation on charge generation. Here, we studied the impact of aggregation on charge generation using transient absorption spectroscopy, neutron scattering, and at. force microscopy. Our measurements indicate that the 1,8-diiodooctane additive can change the aggregation behavior of poly(benzodithiophene-alt-dithienyl difluorobenzotriazole) (PBnDT-FTAZ) and phenyl-C61-butyric acid Me ester (PCBM)polymer blends and impact the charge generation process. Our observations show that the charge generation can be optimized by tuning the aggregation in polymer blends, which can be beneficial for the design of highly efficient fullerene-based org. photovoltaic devices.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3MXisVSltbY%253D&md5=6cf125fe75dfbbc22b6725fe130b8b30
        open URL
      12. 12
        El-Khouly, M. E.; Fukuzumi, S.; D’Souza, F. Photosynthetic Antenna–Reaction Center Mimicry by Using Boron Dipyrromethene Sensitizers. Chem. Phys. Chem. 2014, 15, 30– 47,  DOI: 10.1002/cphc.201300715
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12
        Photosynthetic antenna-reaction center mimicry by using boron dipyrromethene sensitizers
        El-Khouly Mohamed E; Fukuzumi Shunichi; D'Souza Francis
        Chemphyschem : a European journal of chemical physics and physical chemistry (2014), 15 (1), 30-47 ISSN:.
        Various molecular and supramolecular systems have been synthesized and characterized recently to mimic the functions of photosynthesis, in which solar energy conversion is achieved. Artificial photosynthesis consists of light-harvesting and charge-separation processes together with catalytic units of water oxidation and reduction. Among the organic molecules, derivatives of BF2-chelated dipyrromethene (BODIPY), "porphyrin's little sister", have been widely used in constructing these artificial photosynthetic models due to their unique properties. In these photosynthetic models, BODIPYs act as not only excellent antenna molecules, but also as electron-donor and -acceptor molecules in both the covalently linked molecular and supramolecular systems formed by axial coordination, hydrogen bonding, or crown ether complexation. The relationships between the structures and photochemical reactivities of these novel molecular and supramolecular systems are discussed in relation to the efficiency of charge separation and charge recombination. Femto- and nanosecond transient absorption and photoelectrochemical techniques have been employed in these studies to give clear evidence for the occurrence of energy- and electron-transfer reactions and to determine their rates and efficiencies.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC2c7nvFensw%253D%253D&md5=de1850c67dec1899a61fe14b3dc030f9
        open URL
      13. 13
        Guo, S.; Ma, L.; Zhao, J.; Küçüköz, B.; Karatay, A.; Hayvali, M.; Yaglioglu, H. G.; Elmali, A. BODIPY Triads Triplet Photosensitizers Enhanced with Intramolecular Resonance Energy Transfer (RET): Broadband Visible Light Absorption and Application in Photooxidation. Chem. Sci. 2014, 5, 489– 500,  DOI: 10.1039/C3SC52323C
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13
        BODIPY triads triplet photosensitizers enhanced with intramolecular resonance energy transfer (RET): broadband visible light absorption and application in photooxidation
        Guo, Song; Ma, Lihua; Zhao, Jianzhang; Kuecuekoez, Betuel; Karatay, Ahmet; Hayvali, Mustafa; Yaglioglu, H. Gul; Elmali, Ayhan
        Chemical Science (2014), 5 (2), 489-500CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Resonance energy transfer (RET) was used to enhance the light absorption in triad triplet photosensitizers to access strong and broadband absorption in visible region (from 450-750 nm). This strategy was demonstrated by prepn. of (BODIPY)2-diiodo-aza-BODIPY triad (B-2) and (carbazole-styryl BODIPY)2-diiodo-aza-BODIPY triad (B-3), in which the energy donor (BODIPY or styryl-BODIPY) and the energy acceptor (aza-BODIPY, also as the spin converter) parts were connected by click chem. Both the energy donors and the energy acceptors show strong absorption in the visible spectral region, but at different wavelengths, therefore the triads show broadband absorption in visible spectra region, e.g. the two major absorption bands of B-3 are located at 593 nm and 683 nm, with .vepsiln. up to 220 000 M-1 cm-1 and 81 000 M-1 cm-1, resp. For comparison, a ref. compd. with only diiodo-aza-BODIPY as the light-harvesting unit was prepd. (B-1), which shows only one major absorption band in visible spectral region. Fluorescence studies indicated intramol. energy transfer for these BODIPY hybrids, a conclusion which is supported by the femtosecond time-resolved transient absorption spectroscopy. Nanosecond transient absorption spectra show that triplet excited states of the dyad and the triad are localized on the iodo-aza-BODIPY part. The compds. were used as triplet photosensitizers for singlet oxygen (1O2) mediated photooxidn. of 1,5-dihydroxylnaphthalene and the photosensitizing ability of the new triplet photosensitizers are more efficient than the mono-chromophore based triplet photosensitizers. The mol. design rationale of these RET-enhanced multi-chromophore triplet photosensitizer is useful for development of efficient triplet photosensitizers and for their applications in photocatalysis, photodynamic therapy, photovoltaics and upconversion.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXitVSqtLfO&md5=7bfe34cd592b4a87fa0702db39a92376
        open URL
      14. 14
        Bañuelos, J. BODIPY Dye, the Most Versatile Fluorophore Ever?. Chem. Rec. 2016, 16, 335– 348,  DOI: 10.1002/tcr.201500238
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14
        BODIPY Dye, the Most Versatile Fluorophore Ever?
        Banuelos, Jorge
        Chemical Record (2016), 16 (1), 335-348CODEN: CRHEAK; ISSN:1528-0691. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        BODIPY laser dyes constitute a fascinating topic of research in modern photochem. due to the large variety of options its chromophore offers, which is ready available for a multitude of synthetic routes. Indeed, in the literature one can find a huge battery of compds. based on the indacene core. The possibility of modulating the spectroscopic properties or inducing new photophys. processes by the substitution pattern of the BODIPY dyes has boosted the no. of scientific and technol. applications for these fluorophores. Along the following lines, I will overview the main results achieved in our lab. with BODIPYs oriented to optoelectronic as well to biophotonic applications, stressing the more relevant photophys. issues to be considered in the design of a tailor-made BODIPY for a certain application and pointing out some of the remaining challenges.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XmslGrtw%253D%253D&md5=52a8451c46c239a7ceb0b5f807e0b76d

      15. 15
        Bandi, V.; Gobeze, H. B.; D’Souza, F. Ultrafast Photoinduced Electron Transfer and Charge Stabilization in Donor–Acceptor Dyads Capable of Harvesting Near-Infrared Light. Chem. – Eur. J. 2015, 21, 11483– 11494,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201500728
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        15
        Ultrafast photoinduced electron transfer and charge stabilization in donor-acceptor dyads capable of harvesting near-infrared light
        Bandi, Venugopal; Gobeze, Habtom B.; D'Souza, Francis
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2015), 21 (32), 11483-11494CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        To harvest energy from the near-IR (near-IR) and IR (IR) regions of the electromagnetic spectrum, which constitutes nearly 70% of the solar radiation, there is a great demand for near-IR and IR light-absorbing sensitizers that are capable of undergoing ultrafast photoinduced electron transfer when connected to a suitable electron acceptor. Towards achieving this goal, in the present study, we report multistep syntheses of dyads derived from structurally modified BF2-chelated azadipyrromethene (ADP; to extend absorption and emission into the near-IR region) and fullerene as electron-donor and electron-acceptor entities, resp. The newly synthesized dyads were fully characterized based on optical absorbance, fluorescence, geometry optimization, and electrochem. studies. The established energy level diagram revealed the possibility of electron transfer either from the singlet excited near-IR sensitizer or singlet excited fullerene. Femtosecond and nanosecond transient absorption studies were performed to gather evidence of excited state electron transfer and to evaluate the kinetics of charge sepn. and charge recombination processes. These studies revealed the occurrence of ultrafast photoinduced electron transfer leading to charge stabilization in the dyads, and populating the triplet states of ADP, benzanulated-ADP and benzanulated thiophene-ADP in the resp. dyads, and triplet state of C60 in the case of BF2-chelated dipyrromethene derived dyad during charge recombination. The present findings reveal that these sensitizers are suitable for harvesting light energy from the near-IR region of the solar spectrum and for building fast-responding optoelectronic devices operating under near-IR radiation input.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtFWgtb7N&md5=33d56a413a5f702040e26bed5f244a5a
        open URL
      16. 16
        Liu, J.-Y.; Hou, X.-N.; Tian, Y.; Jiang, L.; Deng, S.; Röder, B.; Ermilov, E. A. Photoinduced Energy and Charge Transfer in a Bis (triphenylamine)–BODIPY–C60 Artificial Photosynthetic System. RSC Adv. 2016, 6, 57293– 57305,  DOI: 10.1039/C6RA06841C
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16
        Photoinduced energy and charge transfer in a bis(triphenylamine)-BODIPY-C60 artificial photosynthetic system
        Liu, Jian-Yong; Hou, Xue-Ni; Tian, Ye; Jiang, Lizhi; Deng, Shuiquan; Roder, Beate; Ermilov, Eugeny A.
        RSC Advances (2016), 6 (62), 57293-57305CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Triphenylamines (TPAs), boron dipyrromethenes (BODIPYs) and fullerenes C60 are excellent building blocks for the design of artificial photosynthetic systems. In the present work, we report the synthesis, characterization and detailed photophys. studies of a novel (TPA)2-BODIPY-C60 tetrad in polar and nonpolar solvents. The absorption spectrum of this compd. covered virtually the entire visible region (350-700 nm) and could be interpreted as a superposition of the spectra of individual components. Upon TPA-part excitation, a fast and very efficient excitation energy transfer (EET) delivers the excitation to the BODIPY moiety resulting in complete quenching of the TPA first excited singlet state as well as the appearance of the BODIPY fluorescence. The efficiency of EET process was estd. to be 1. Direct or indirect (via EET) excitation of the BODIPY-part of the tetrad is followed by photoinduced charge transfer to the charge-sepd. state BODIPẎ +-C60̇ - irresp. of the solvent used. In polar N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) charge recombination occurs directly to the ground state with the charge recombination rate, kCR, slower than 108 s-1, whereas in nonpolar toluene (TOL) a small energy gap between the charge-sepd. state and first excited singlet state of the BODIPY moiety facilitates the back charge transfer process. The latter results in the appearance of thermally activated delayed fluorescence. The rate of charge sepn. was found to be ca. 2 times faster in TOL than in DMF.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XpsVGls7o%253D&md5=439473bbae8bfba080d3e9e4f8f7d479
        open URL
      17. 17
        Gao, D.; Aly, S. M.; Karsenti, P.-L.; Brisard, G.; Harvey, P. D. Ultrafast Energy and Electron Transfers in Structurally Well Addressable BODIPY-Porphyrin-Fullerene Polyads. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2017, 19, 2926– 2939,  DOI: 10.1039/C6CP08000F
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17
        Ultrafast energy and electron transfers in structurally well addressable BODIPY-porphyrin-fullerene polyads
        Gao, Di; Aly, Shawkat M.; Karsenti, Paul-Ludovic; Brisard, Gessie; Harvey, Pierre D.
        Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2017), 19 (4), 2926-2939CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Two electron transfer polyads built upon [C60]-[ZnP]-[BODIPY] (1) and [ZnP]-[ZnP](-[BODIPY])(-[C60]) (2), where [C60] = N-methyl-2-phenyl-3,4-fulleropyrrolidine, [BODIPY] = boron dipyrromethane, and [ZnP] = zinc(II) porphyrin, were synthesized along with their corresponding energy transfer polyads [ZnP]-[BODIPY] (1a) and [ZnP]-[ZnP]-[BODIPY] (2a) as well as relevant models. These polyads were studied using cyclic voltammetry, DFT computations, steady state and time-resolved fluorescence spectroscopy, and fs transient absorption spectroscopy. The rates for energy transfer, kET, [BODIPY]* → [ZnP] are ∼2.8 × 1010 s-1 for both 1a and 2a, with an efficiency of 99%. Concurrently, the fast appearance of the [C60]-· anion for 1 and 2 indicates that the charge sepn. occurs on the 20-30 ps timescale with the rates of electron transfer, ket, [ZnP]*/[C60] → [ZnP]+· /[C60]-· of ∼0.9 × 1010 to ∼3.8 × 1010 s-1. The latter value is among the fastest for these types of polyads. Conversely, the charge recombination operates on the ns timescale. These rates are comparable to or faster than those reported for other more flexible [C60]-[ZnP]-[BODIPY] polyads, which can be rationalized by the donor-acceptor sepns.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XitFCmu73L&md5=447b52e8c8d97c1360d8e859666afd92

      18. 18
        Amin, A. N.; El-Khouly, M. E.; Subbaiyan, N. K.; Zandler, M. E.; Fukuzumi, S.; D’Souza, F. A novel BF 2-chelated azadipyrromethene–fullerene dyad: synthesis, electrochemistry and photodynamics. Chem. Commun. 2012, 48, 206– 208,  DOI: 10.1039/C1CC16071K
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        18
        A novel BF2-chelated azadipyrromethene-fullerene dyad: synthesis, electrochemistry and photodynamics
        Amin, Anu N.; El-Khouly, Mohamed E.; Subbaiyan, Navaneetha K.; Zandler, Melvin E.; Fukuzumi, Shunichi; D'Souza, Francis
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2012), 48 (2), 206-208CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The synthesis, structure, electrochem. and photodynamics of a BF2-chelated azadipyrromethene-fullerene dyad are reported in comparison with BF2-chelated azadipyrromethene without fullerene. The attachment of fullerene resulted in efficient generation of the triplet excited state of the azadipyrromethene via photoinduced electron transfer.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhsFGqu77O&md5=3f2dad8d2ef1977e7d6f0aa9ebea0748

      19. 19
        Shi, W.-J.; El-Khouly, M. E.; Ohkubo, K.; Fukuzumi, S.; Ng, D. K. Photosynthetic Antenna-Reaction Center Mimicry with a Covalently Linked Monostyryl Boron-Dipyrromethene–Aza-Boron-Dipyrromethene–C60 Triad. Chem. – Eur. J. 2013, 19, 11332– 11341,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201300318
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        19
        Photosynthetic Antenna-Reaction Center Mimicry with a Covalently Linked Monostyryl Boron-Dipyrromethene-Aza-Boron-Dipyrromethene-C60 Triad
        Shi, Wen-Jing; El-Khouly, Mohamed E.; Ohkubo, Kei; Fukuzumi, Shunichi; Ng, Dennis K. P.
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2013), 19 (34), 11332-11341CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        An efficient functional mimic of the photosynthetic antenna-reaction center has been designed and synthesized. The simulation, physicochem. contains a near-IR-absorbing aza-boron-dipyrromethene (ADP) that is connected to a monostyryl boron-dipyrromethene (BDP) by a click reaction and to a fullerene (C60) using the Prato reaction. The intramol. photoinduced energy and electron-transfer processes of this triad as well as the corresponding dyads BDP-ADP and ADP-C60 have been studied with steady-state and time-resolved absorption and fluorescence spectroscopic methods in benzonitrile. Upon excitation, the BDP moiety of the triad is significantly quenched due to energy transfer to the ADP core, which subsequently transfers an electron to the fullerene unit. Cyclic and differential pulse voltammetric studies have revealed the redox states of the components, which allow estn. of the energies of the charge-sepd. states. Such calcns. show that electron transfer from the singlet excited ADP (1ADP*) to C60 yielding ADP.+-C60.- is energetically favorable. By using femtosecond laser radiation flash photolysis, concrete evidence has been obtained for the occurrence of energy transfer from 1BDP* to ADP in the dyad BDP-ADP and electron transfer from 1ADP* to C60 in the dyad ADP-C60. Sequential energy and electron transfer have also been clearly obsd. in the triad BDP-ADP-C60. By monitoring the rise of ADP emission, it has been found that the rate of energy transfer is fast (≈1011 s-1). The dynamics of electron transfer through 1ADP* has also been studied by monitoring the formation of C60 radical anion at 1000 nm. A fast charge-sepn. process from 1ADP* to C60 has been detected, which gives the relatively long-lived BDP-ADP.+C60.- with a lifetime of 1.47 ns. As shown by nanosecond transient absorption measurements, the charge-sepd. state decays slowly to populate mainly the triplet state of ADP before returning to the ground state. These findings show that the dyads BDP-ADP and ADP-C60, and the triad BDP-ADP-C60 are interesting artificial analogs that can mimic the antenna and reaction center of the natural photosynthetic systems.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtFShsLbJ&md5=763c155b424c4687e01ef0c0e7983b94
        open URL
      20. 20
        Yee, M.-c.; Fas, S. C.; Stohlmeyer, M. M.; Wandless, T. J.; Cimprich, K. A. A cell-Permeable, Activity-Based Probe for Protein and Lipid Kinases. J. Biol. Chem. 2005, 280, 29053– 29059,  DOI: 10.1074/jbc.M504730200
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        20
        A Cell-permeable, Activity-based Probe for Protein and Lipid Kinases
        Yee, Muh-ching; Fas, Stefanie C.; Stohlmeyer, Michelle M.; Wandless, Thomas J.; Cimprich, Karlene A.
        Journal of Biological Chemistry (2005), 280 (32), 29053-29059CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
        Protein and lipid kinases are two important classes of biomedically relevant enzymes. The expression and activity of many kinases are known to be dysregulated in a variety of diseases, and proteomic tools that can assess the presence and activity of these enzymes are likely to be useful for their evaluation. Because many of the mechanisms by which protein kinases can become unregulated involve post-translational modifications or changes in protein localization, they can only be detected by examg. protein activity, sometimes within the context of the living cell. Wortmannin is a steroid-derived fungal metabolite that covalently inhibits both protein and lipid kinases. Here the authors describe the synthesis of three wortmannin derivs., biotin-wortmannin, BODIPY-wortmannin, and tetramethylrhodamine-wortmannin. The authors demonstrate that these reagents exhibit reactivity similarly as wortmannin and react with members of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase and PI3-kinase related kinase families in cellular lysates. Moreover, in some cases these reagents can differentiate between the active and inactive forms of the enzyme, indicating that they are activity-based probes. The reagents also exhibit complementary properties. The biotin-wortmannin reagent is effective in the isolation of labeled proteins; all three can be used for protein labeling, and BODIPY-wortmannin is cell-permeable and can be used to label proteins within cells.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXntVegs70%253D&md5=ea78c6386b56181265e49ec619ee7e9e
        open URL
      21. 21
        Tan, K.; Jaquinod, L.; Paolesse, R.; Nardis, S.; Di Natale, C.; Di Carlo, A.; Prodi, L.; Montalti, M.; Zaccheroni, N.; Smith, K. M. Synthesis and Characterization of β-Fused Porphyrin-BODIPY Dyads. Tetrahedron 2004, 60, 1099– 1106,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tet.2003.11.072
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        21
        Synthesis and characterization of β-fused porphyrin-BODIPY dyads
        Tan, Kenyu; Jaquinod, Laurent; Paolesse, Roberto; Nardis, Sara; Di Natale, Corrado; Di Carlo, Aldo; Prodi, Luca; Montalti, Marco; Zaccheroni, Nelsi; Smith, Kevin M.
        Tetrahedron (2004), 60 (5), 1099-1106CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
        Novel dyads in which a porphyrin ring is directly fused through two β-pyrrolic carbons to a BODIPY moiety were prepd. using a stepwise approach starting from the Cu(II) complex of pyrrolo[2,3-c]-5,10,15,20-tetraphenylporphyrin. Formylation and reaction with 3,5-dimethylpyrrole afforded Cu(HL) (H3L = I); subsequent BF2 complexation gave the TPP-BODIPY dyad CuL(BF2) in reasonable yields. Demetalation in TFA/H2SO4 led to the corresponding free base BF2(H2L), opening the way to the subsequent prepn. of ZnL(BF2). Both BF2(H2L) and ZnL(BF2) exhibited complex optical spectra with an intensely red-shifted Q-band. Luminescence spectra displayed a very intense band around 700 nm making these species suitable as near-IR dyes and sensors in biol. media. Optical analyses of BF2(H2L), using the INDO/SCI technique, were performed to obtain information to establish the origin of the novel optical properties. The optical properties of BF2(H2L) cannot be attributed to deformation of the mol. skeleton, but derive from the increased extension of the conjugation between the TPP and BODIPY π-systems.

        Gautam, P.; Misra, R.; Thomas, M. B.; D’Souza, F. Ultrafast Charge-Separation in Triphenylamine-BODIPY-Derived Triads Carrying Centrally Positioned, Highly Electron-Deficient, Dicyanoquinodimethane or Tetracyanobutadiene Electron-Acceptors. Chem. – Eur. J. 2017, 23, 9192– 9200,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201701604
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        22
        Ultrafast Charge-Separation in Triphenylamine-BODIPY-Derived Triads Carrying Centrally Positioned, Highly Electron-Deficient, Dicyanoquinodimethane or Tetracyanobutadiene Electron-Acceptors
        Gautam, Prabhat; Misra, Rajneesh; Thomas, Michael B.; D'Souza, Francis
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2017), 23 (38), 9192-9200CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A series of new triphenylamine (TPA)-substituted BODIPYs 1-3 have been designed and synthesized through the Pd-catalyzed Sonogashira cross-coupling and [2+2] cycloaddn.-retroelectrocyclization reactions in good yields. This procedure yielded highly electron-deficient tetracyanobutadiene (TCBD) or dicyanoquinodimethane (DCNQ) electron-acceptor units centrally located at the TPA-BODIPY system. As a consequence, significant perturbation of the photonic and electronic properties was obsd. The triads 2 and 3 showed red-shifted absorption, in addn. to a strong charge-transfer-type absorption in the case of 3. The electrochem. studies revealed multi-redox processes involving the TPA, TCBD or DCNQ and BODIPY entities. The computational studies were performed at the B3LYP/6-31G** level to elucidate the geometry and electronic structures. An energy level diagram established for triads 2 and 3 revealed that the photoinduced charge-sepn. from the 1BODIPY* is thermodynamically possible. In addn., charge transfer from TPA to TCBD in 2 and DCNQ in 3 was also possible. These charge transfer mechanisms were confirmed by photochem. studies performed using time-resolved emission and femtosecond-transient-absorption studies in solvents of varying polarity. Ultrafast charge-sepn. has been witnessed in these closely spaced, strongly interacting triads. The charge-sepd. state returned to the ground state without populating the 3BODIPY*.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Srinivasa Rao, R.; Bagui, A.; Rao, G. H.; Gupta, V.; Singh, S. P. Achieving the Highest Efficiency Using a BODIPY Core Decorated with Dithiafulvalene Wings for Small Molecule Based Solution-Processed Organic Solar Cells. Chem. Commun. 2017, 53, 6953– 6956,  DOI: 10.1039/C7CC03363J

        Achieving the highest efficiency using a BODIPY core decorated with dithiafulvalene wings for small molecule based solution-processed organic solar cells
        Srinivasa Rao, R.; Bagui, Anirban; Hanumantha Rao, G.; Gupta, Vinay; Singh, Surya Prakash
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2017), 53 (51), 6953-6956CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A novel B dipyrromethene based dye, coded as BODIPY-DTF, decorated with dithiafulvalene wings was developed for solar cell application.         https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXptlKmsLs%253D&md5=a3f7d0ffe81168ed18ae3ed2708111b4

      25. 25
        Heeger, A. J. 25th Anniversary Article, Bulk Heterojunction Solar Cells: Understanding the Mechanism of Operation. Adv. Mater. 2014, 26, 10– 28,  DOI: 10.1002/adma.201304373
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        25
        25th Anniversary Article: Bulk Heterojunction Solar Cells: Understanding the Mechanism of Operation
        Heeger, Alan J.
        Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2014), 26 (1), 10-28CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. The status of understanding of the operation of bulk heterojunction solar cells is discussed. Because the carrier photoexcitation recombination lengths are typically 10 nm in these disordered materials, the length scale for self-assembly must be on the order of 10-20 nm. Expts. have verified the existence of the bulk heterojunction nanostructure, but the morphol. remains complex and a limiting factor. Three steps are required for generation of elec. power: (a) absorption of photons from the sun; (b) photoinduced charge sepn. and the generation of mobile carriers; and (c) collection of electrons and holes at opposite electrodes. The ultrafast charge transfer process arises from fundamental quantum uncertainty; mobile carriers are directly generated (electrons in the acceptor domains and holes in the donor domains) by the ultrafast charge transfer (≈70%) with ≈30% generated by exciton diffusion to a charge sepg. heterojunction. Sweep-out of the mobile carriers by the internal field prior to recombination is essential for high performance. Bimol. recombination dominates in materials where the donor and acceptor phases are pure. Impurities degrade performance by introducing Shockley-Read-Hall decay. The review concludes with a summary of the problems to be solved to achieve the predicted power conversion efficiencies of >20% for a single cell.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhvVykur%252FN&md5=f57101d8c6e984e8760edcd6651e124a
        open URL
      26. 26
        Huang, Y.; Kramer, E. J.; Heeger, A. J.; Bazan, G. C. Bulk Heterojunction Solar Cells: Morphology and Performance Relationships. Chem. Rev. 2014, 114, 7006– 7043,  DOI: 10.1021/cr400353v
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        26

        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2014), 114 (14), 7006-7043CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review of some of the basic aspects of morphol. and performance relations of bulk heterojunction solar cells.

      28. 28
        Cabrera-Espinoza, A.; Insuasty, B.; Ortiz, A. Synthesis, The Electronic Properties and Efficient Photoinduced Electron Transfer of New Pyrrolidine [60]Fullerene-and Isoxazoline [60]Fullerene-BODIPY Dyads: Nitrile Oxide Cycloaddition Under Mild Conditions Using PIFA.         Synthesis, the electronic properties and efficient photoinduced electron transfer of new pyrrolidine[60]fullerene- and isoxazoline[60]fullerene-BODIPY dyads: nitrile oxide cycloaddition under mild conditions using PIFA
        Cabrera-Espinoza, Andrea; Insuasty, Braulio; Ortiz, Alejandro
        New Journal of Chemistry (2017), 41 (17), 9061-9069CODEN: NJCHE5; ISSN:1144-0546. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Two new BODIPY-C60 dyads, with a pyrrolidine linker I (BDP-Pyr) and an isoxazoline linker II (BDP-Is) between the two electroactive units, have been synthesized and characterized. Their photophys. and electrochem. properties have been studied in soln. by comparing with the ref. compds. BDP and [60]fullerene. Both BODIPY-C60 derivs. strongly absorb visible light and by photoexcitation at the BDP unit, these dyads undergo photoinduced electron transfer affording the corresponding charge-sepd. species. Based on their redox potentials, also the direction of the charge transfer is revealed and a comparison between the dyads with respect to C60 suggested that the new BDP-Is deriv. showed a better electron affinity than BDP-Pyr and C60. In addn., the exptl. studies were complemented by a theor. anal. based on semiempirical computations which allowed confirming of the charge transfer mechanism from the BDP core to the C60 cages.

        Synthesis, characterization and photophysics of novel BODIPY linked to dumbbell systems based on Fullerene[60]pyrrolidine and Fullerene[60]isoxazoline
        Calderon-Cerquera, Kyangzi; Parra, Alejandra; Madrid-Usuga, Duvalier; Cabrera-Espinoza, Andrea; Melo-Luna, Carlos A.; Reina, John H.; Insuasty, Braulio; Ortiz, Alejandro
        Dyes and Pigments (2021), 184 (), 108752CODEN: DYPIDX; ISSN:0143-7208. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        Pyrrolidine [60]Fullerene-BODIPY (BDP(Pyr)2) and Isoxazoline [60]Fullerene-BODIPY (BDP(Iso)2) are two C60 fragments linked in a dumbbell system to the boron-dipyrromethene core (BODIPY). We have synthesized and characterized these systems by NMR, MALDI-TOF, mass spectroscopy, and time-resolved spectroscopy. The photophys. properties of these novel compds. show a strong interaction in the excited state, generating charged species between BODIPY and the two C60 units. Furthermore, by employing cyclic voltammetry and pulse differential studies, we measured this electronic interaction: it is stronger in BDP(Iso)2 than in BDP(Pyr)2, likely due to the isoxazoline ring conjugation which increases the interaction between the electro-attractive units. This result is confirmed by fluorescence lifetime measurements, in which the BDP(Iso)2 shows a better performance even at different solvent polarities. Finally, we attribute the transitions of the HOMO→LUMO and HOMO→LUMO+1 orbitals to the max. absorption wavelength, which produces the S1 and S2 excited states, resp., for which the intramol. charge transport is stronger between the BODIPY and the two C60 units.

        Becke, A. D. Density-Functional Thermochemistry III. The Role of Exact Exchange. J. Chem. Phys. 1993, 98, 5648– 5652,  DOI: 10.1063/1.464913
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30
        Density-functional thermochemistry. III. The role of exact exchange
        Becke, Axel D.
        Journal of Chemical Physics (1993), 98 (7), 5648-52CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606.
        Despite the remarkable thermochem. accuracy of Kohn-Sham d.-functional theories with gradient corrections for exchange-correlation, the author believes that further improvements are unlikely unless exact-exchange information is considered. Arguments to support this view are presented, and a semiempirical exchange-correlation functional (contg. local-spin-d., gradient, and exact-exchange terms) is tested for 56 atomization energies, 42 ionization potentials, 8 proton affinities, and 10 total at. energies of first- and second-row systems. This functional performs better than previous functionals with gradient corrections only, and fits expt. atomization energies with an impressively small av. abs. deviation of 2.4 kcal/mol.

        Ganji, M. D.; Tajbakhsh, M.; Kariminasab, M.; Alinezhad, H. Tuning the LUMO Level of Organic Photovoltaic Solar Cells by Conjugately Fusing Graphene Flake: A DFT-B3LYP Study. Phys. E 2016, 81, 108– 115,  DOI: 10.1016/j.physe.2016.03.008
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        32
        Tuning the LUMO level of organic photovoltaic solar cells by conjugately fusing graphene flake: A DFT-B3LYP study
        Ganji, M. Darvish; Tajbakhsh, M.; Kariminasab, M.; Alinezhad, H.
        Physica E: Low-Dimensional Systems & Nanostructures (Amsterdam, Netherlands) (2016), 81 (), 108-115CODEN: PELNFM; ISSN:1386-9477. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The efficiency of polymer solar cells can be essentially enhanced by improving the performance of electron acceptor materials esp. by increasing its LUMO (LUMO) level. To this aim, the electronic properties of an extremely π-extended system, graphene flake and functionalized graphene flake with phenyl-C-butyric Me ester (PCBM) group, were investigated and compared with those of C60 ones. Several properties of phenyl-C61-butyric Me ester ([C60]PCBM) derivs. have been calcd. and compared against the exptl. and other theor. results. All geometrical and electronic structures calcns. were carried out by using the d. functional theory (DFT) method at the B3LYP level of theory. The results show that the Ph ring of [C60]PCBM was substituted with the methoxy groups to increase the LUMO level of the resp. system which is in agreement with other studies. We found that graphene flake functionalized by methoxy-PCBM group offer significant increase in the value of the LUMO energy level in comparison with C60 counterpart. Furthermore, the electrophilicity of this compd. is lower than that of the other counterparts, which results in higher open circuit voltage (Voc) value in the photovoltaic device. These findings could provide fundamental insights in improving the Voc value as well as raising the LUMO levels of electron acceptor materials and may also serve as an alternative strategy to increase open circuit voltage in polymer solar cells.

        Takano, Y.; Houk, K. Benchmarking the Conductor-Like Polarizable Continuum Model (CPCM) for Aqueous Solvation Free Energies of Neutral and Ionic Organic Molecules. J. Chem. Theory Comput. 2005, 1, 70– 77,  DOI: 10.1021/ct049977a
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        33
        Benchmarking the Conductor-like Polarizable Continuum Model (CPCM) for Aqueous Solvation Free Energies of Neutral and Ionic Organic Molecules
        Takano Yu; Houk K N
        Journal of chemical theory and computation (2005), 1 (1), 70-7 ISSN:1549-9618.
        The conductor-like polarizable continuum model (CPCM) using several cavity models is applied to compute aqueous solvation free energies for a number of organic molecules (30 neutral molecules, 21 anions, and 19 cations). The calculated solvation free energies are compared to the available experimental data from the viewpoint of cavity models, computational methods, calculation time, and aqueous pKa values. The HF/6-31+G(d)//HF/6-31+G(d) and the HF/6-31+G(d)//B3LYP/6-31+G(d) with the UAKS cavities, in which radii are optimized with PBE0/6-31G(d), provide aqueous solvation effects in best agreement with available experimental data. The mean absolute deviations from experiment are 2.6 kcal/mol. The MP2/6-31++G(d,p)//HF/6-31+G(d) with the CPCM-UAKS(HF/6-31+G(d)) calculation is also performed for the base-catalyzed hydrolysis of methyl acetate in water.

        Chiu, K. Y.; Govindan, V.; Lin, L.-C.; Huang, S.-H.; Hu, J.-C.; Lee, K.-M.; Tsai, H.-H. G.; Chang, S.-H.; Wu, C.-G. DPP Containing D−π–A Organic Dyes Toward Highly Efficient Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells. Dyes Pigm. 2016, 125, 27– 35,  DOI: 10.1016/j.dyepig.2015.09.033

        DPP containing D-π-A organic dyes toward highly efficient dye-sensitized solar cells
        Chiu, Kuo Yuan; Govindan, Venkatesan; Lin, Ling-Chuan; Huang, Shin-Han; Hu, Jia-Cheng; Lee, Kun-Mu; Tsai, Hui-Hsu Gavin; Chang, Sheng-Hsiung; Wu, Chun-Guey
        Dyes and Pigments (2016), 125 (), 27-35CODEN: DYPIDX; ISSN:0143-7208. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        Two diketopyrrolopyrrole (DPP) contg. D-π-A org. dyes, named as TEDBn and TEDTh were prepd. Their optical, electrochem. and photophys. properties were studied and their application in dye-sensitized solar cells (DSCs) was demonstrated. The broaden absorption and low-energy λmax of DPP contg. dyes were contributed from DPP bridge and EDOT π-conjugated moiety. Compared to TEDTh, TEDBn has smaller absorption coeff. and higher optical bandgap. Nevertheless the power conversion efficiency (PCE) of TEDBn based DSC is 7.2% which is larger than that of TEDTh based DSC and 90% of N719 based cell. The higher PCE of TEDBn based device originates from both higher open-circuit voltage (VOC) and short-circuit current (JSC). Femtosecond time-resolved photoluminescence data show that the electron injection at TEDBn/TiO2 is more efficient than that at TEDTh/TiO2 interface, resulting in higher JSC (and IPCE) of TEDBn based DSC. D. function theory (DFT) calcns. revealed that TEDBn is a linear structure which leads to higher dye loading on TiO2 than TEDTh which featured a bend conformation, better TiO2 surface coverage, resulting in larger VOC. Therefore, the overall efficiency of the cell sensitized by TEDBn is better than that the devices based on TEDTh.

        Janak, J. Proof that ∂E/∂ni = ϵ in density-functional theory. Phys. Rev. B 1978, 18, 7165,  DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevB.18.7165

        35
        Proof that .vdelta.E/.vdelta.ni = εi in density-functional theory
        Janak, J. F.
        Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics (1978), 18 (12), 7165-8CODEN: PRBMDO; ISSN:0163-1829.
        The variation of the total energy, as constructed in d.-functional theory, with respect to an orbital occupation in equal to the eigenvalue of that orbital, independent of the detailed form of the exchange-correlation functional. This leads to a rigorous connection between the ground-state energies of N- and (N + 1)-particle systems, which is useful in the calcn. of certain excitation energies.

        Vandewal, K. Interfacial Charge Transfer States in Condensed Phase Systems. Annu. Rev. Phys. Chem. 2016, 67, 113– 133,  DOI: 10.1146/annurev-physchem-040215-112144
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        36
        Interfacial Charge Transfer States in Condensed Phase Systems
        Vandewal, Koen
        Annual Review of Physical Chemistry (2016), 67 (), 113-133CODEN: ARPLAP; ISSN:0066-426X. (Annual Reviews)
        Intermol. charge transfer (CT) states at the interface between electron-donating (D) and electron-accepting (A) materials in org. thin films are characterized by absorption and emission bands within the optical gap of the interfacing materials. CT states efficiently generate charge carriers for some D-A combinations, and others show high fluorescence quantum efficiencies. These properties are exploited in org. solar cells, photodetectors, and light-emitting diodes. This review summarizes exptl. and theor. work on the electronic structure and interfacial energy landscape at condensed matter D-A interfaces. Recent findings on photogeneration and recombination of free charge carriers via CT states are discussed, and relations between CT state properties and optoelectronic device parameters are clarified.

        Su, W.-C.; Lee, C.-C.; Li, Y.-Z.; Liu, S.-W. Influence of Singlet and Charge-Transfer Excitons on the Open-Circuit Voltage of Rubrene/Fullerene Organic Photovoltaic Device. ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2016, 8, 28757– 28762,  DOI: 10.1021/acsami.6b08363
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        37
        Influence of Singlet and Charge-Transfer Excitons on the Open-Circuit Voltage of Rubrene/Fullerene Organic Photovoltaic Device
        Su, Wei-Cheng; Lee, Chih-Chien; Li, Ya-Ze; Liu, Shun-Wei
        ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces (2016), 8 (42), 28757-28762CODEN: AAMICK; ISSN:1944-8244. (American Chemical Society)
        The open-circuit voltage (VOC) of rubrene/C60 org. photovoltaic (OPV) devices can be substantially improved by changing the rubrene thickness. A shoulder exhibited at 500-550 nm was obsd. The singlet excitons of rubrene were increased when the thickness of the rubrene layer was increased. Capacitance-voltage measurements were conducted for estg. the built-in potential of the devices. The calcd. VOC was higher than that of the expt., thus indicating that energetic losses occurred in the devices. The authors reused the reciprocity and revised Marcus theory for detg. the charge-transfer (CT) properties of the devices. The CT properties of the CT states at the rubrene/C60 interface remained similar. The nonradiative energetic losses become smaller when the rubrene layer was increased, thus indicating the bimol. recombination was increased. The increased recombination thermally activated the electrons in C60 into rubrene for forming the singlet excitons in rubrene. The redn. in reorganization energy indicated that the electroluminescence of rubrene was enhanced, thereby improving VOC. The two-step thermal activation of C60 electrons and the improved VOC of rubrene were caused by the increased singlet excitons of rubrene.

        Zheng, Z.; Tummala, N. R.; Fu, Y.-T.; Coropceanu, V.; Brédas, J.-L. Charge-Transfer States in Organic Solar Cells: Understanding the Impact of Polarization, Delocalization, and Disorder. ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2017, 9, 18095– 18102,  DOI: 10.1021/acsami.7b02193
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        38
        Charge-Transfer States in Organic Solar Cells: Understanding the Impact of Polarization, Delocalization, and Disorder
        Zheng, Zilong; Tummala, Naga Rajesh; Fu, Yao-Tsung; Coropceanu, Veaceslav; Bredas, Jean-Luc
        ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces (2017), 9 (21), 18095-18102CODEN: AAMICK; ISSN:1944-8244. (American Chemical Society)
        We investigate the impact of electronic polarization, charge delocalization, and energetic disorder on the charge-transfer (CT) states formed at a planar C60/pentacene interface. The ability to examine large complexes contg. up to seven pentacene mols. and three C60 mols. allows us to take explicitly into account the electronic polarization effects. These complexes are extd. from a bilayer architecture modeled by mol. dynamics simulations and evaluated by means of electronic-structure calcns. based on long-range-sepd. functionals (ωB97XD and BNL) with optimized range-sepn. parameters. The energies of the lowest charge-transfer states derived for the large complexes are in very good agreement with the exptl. reported values. The av. singlet-triplet energy splittings of the lowest CT states are calcd. not to exceed 10 meV. The rates of geminate recombination as well as of dissocn. of the triplet excitons are also evaluated. In line with expt., our results indicate that the pentacene triplet excitons generated through singlet fission can dissoc. into sepd. charges on a picosecond time scale, despite the fact that their energy in C60/pentacene heterojunctions is slightly lower than the energies of the lowest CT triplet states.

        Head-Gordon, M.; Grana, A. M.; Maurice, D.; White, C. A. Analysis of Electronic Transitions as the Difference of Electron Attachment and Detachment Densities. J. Phys. Chem. A 1995, 99, 14261– 14270,  DOI: 10.1021/j100039a012
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        39
        Analysis of Electronic Transitions as the Difference of Electron Attachment and Detachment Densities
        Head-Gordon, Martin; Grana, Ana M.; Maurice, David; White, Christopher A.
        Journal of Physical Chemistry (1995), 99 (39), 14261-70CODEN: JPCHAX; ISSN:0022-3654. (American Chemical Society)
        A new method for analyzing calcns. of vertical electronic transitions in mols. is proposed. The one-electron difference d. matrix between the two states is decompd. into the neg. of a detachment d. describing removal of charge from the initial state plus an attachment d. describing its new arrangement in the excited state. This approach relates closely to the simple picture of excited states as electron promotions from occupied to unoccupied orbitals, and yet it can be applied to arbitrarily complex wave functions. The trace of the attachment and detachment densities is a measure of the no. of electrons promoted in a transition. Attachment and detachment densities are calcd. and analyzed for electronic transitions in formaldehyde and the nitromethyl radical.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXnvVOms7w%253D&md5=9721c4610274c7c551261319d9ba2e91

        Blomberg, M. R.; Siegbahn, P. E.; Babcock, G. T. Modeling electron transfer in biochemistry: A quantum chemical study of charge separation in rhodobacter s phaeroides and photosystem ii. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1998, 120, 8812– 8824,  DOI: 10.1021/ja9805268
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        40
        Modeling electron transfer in biochemistry: A quantum chemical study of charge separation in Rhodobacter sphaeroides and photosystem II
        Blomberg, Margareta R. A.; Siegbahn, Per E. M.; Babcock, Gerald T.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1998), 120 (34), 8812-8824CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        High-level quantum chem. methods (hybrid d.-functional type) are applied to the light-driven charge-sepn. process in the photosynthetic reaction centers of both bacteria and photosystem II in green plants. Structural information on the bacterial system provides the basis for choosing the models used in the calcns. The energetics of the electron transfer from the (bacterio)chlorophyll to the quinone are calcd. as well as those of the intermediate step involving the (bacterio)pheophytin. The surrounding protein is treated as a dielec. medium, and the cavities around the solute mols. are detd. by isodensity surfaces. The dielec. effects on the charge-sepn. processes are calcd. to be as large as 50 kcal/mol. It is shown that hydrogen bonding between the chromophores and certain peptide residues as well as the axial histidine ligand on the (bacterio)chlorophylls contributes substantially to the energetics. Good agreement with exptl. estd. driving forces of the different steps is obtained within 2 kcal/mol for the bacteriosystem and within 8 kcal/mol for photosystem II. The results for photosystem II have a lower accuracy, as expected, due to the lack of detailed structural information on this system. Recent low-resoln. data indicating a weaker coupling between the chlorophylls in P680 as compared to that of the special pair in the bacterial systems are taken into account in the calcns. In the bacterial system, charge sepn. to the accessory bacteriochlorophyll is essentially thermoneutral and the P865+BPheo- state is stable by 7.5 kcal/mol. In photosystem II, charge sepn. to the P680+Pheo- state is much less strongly driven, and the absence of an axial histidine ligand to the accessory chlorophyll appears necessary to allow its formation. The creation of the tyrosine radical (YZ) by proton-coupled electron transfer to the photoionized reaction center chlorophyll in photosystem II is also studied. In this case as well, hydrogen bonding to other peptide residues plays an important role in the overall energetic balance of the reaction.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXltVegurg%253D&md5=a2e13ac7c365fdc87ddc752c856a2483

        Powell, D. D.; Wasielewski, M. R.; Ratner, M. A. Redfield Treatment of Multipathway Electron Transfer in Artificial Photosynthetic Systems. J. Phys. Chem. B 2017, 121, 7190– 7203,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpcb.7b02748
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        41
        Redfield Treatment of Multipathway Electron Transfer in Artificial Photosynthetic Systems
        Powell, Daniel D.; Wasielewski, Michael R.; Ratner, Mark A.
        Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2017), 121 (29), 7190-7203CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-5207. (American Chemical Society)
        Coherence effects on electron transfer in a series of sym. and asym. two-, three-, four-, and five-site mol. model systems for photosystem I in cyanobacteria and green plants were studied. The total site energies of the electronic Hamiltonian were calcd. using the d. functional theory (DFT) formalism and included the zero point vibrational energies of the electron donors and acceptors. Site energies and couplings were calcd. using a polarizable continuum model to represent various solvent environments, and the site-to-site couplings were calcd. using fragment charge difference methods at the DFT level of theory. The Redfield formalism was used to propagate the electron d. from the donors to the acceptors, incorporating relaxation and dephasing effects to describe the electron transfer processes. Changing the relative energies of the donor, intermediate acceptor, and final acceptor mols. in these assemblies has profound effects on the electron transfer rates as well as on the amplitude of the quantum oscillations obsd. Increasing the ratio of a particular energy gap to the electronic coupling for a given pair of states leads to weaker quantum oscillations between sites. Biasing the intermediate acceptor energies to slightly favor one pathway leads to a general decrease in electron transfer yield.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtVygtbvN&md5=87daf6d086b13a47b27b6450c4d0b1fe
        open URL
      42. 42
        Veldman, D.; Meskers, S. C.; Janssen, R. A. The energy of charge-transfer states in electron donor–acceptor blends: insight into the energy losses in organic solar cells. Adv. Funct. Mater. 2009, 19, 1939– 1948,  DOI: 10.1002/adfm.200900090
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        42
        The energy of charge-transfer states in electron donor-acceptor blends: insight into the energy losses in organic solar cells
        Veldman, Dirk; Meskers, Stefan C. J.; Janssen, Rene A. J.
        Advanced Functional Materials (2009), 19 (12), 1939-1948CODEN: AFMDC6; ISSN:1616-301X. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Here, a general exptl. method to det. the energy ECT of intermol. charge-transfer (CT) states in electron donor-acceptor (D-A) blends from ground state absorption and electrochem. measurements is proposed. This CT energy is calibrated against the photon energy of max. CT luminescence from selected D-A blends to correct for a const. Coulombic term. It is shown that ECT correlates linearly with the open-circuit voltage (Voc) of photovoltaic devices in D-A blends via eVoc = ECT - 0.5 eV. Using the CT energy, it is found that photoinduced electron transfer (PET) from the lowest singlet excited state (S1 with energy Eg) in the blend to the CT state (S1 → CT) occurs when Eg - ECT > 0.1 eV. Addnl., it is shown that subsequent charge recombination from the CT state to the lowest triplet excited state (ET) of D or A (CT → T1) can occur when ECT - ET > 0.1 eV. From these relations, it is concluded that in D-A blends optimized for photovoltaic action: (i) the max. attainable Voc is ultimately set by the optical band gap (eVoc = Eg - 0.6 eV) and (ii) the singlet-triplet energy gap should be ΔEST < 0.2 eV to prevent recombination to the triplet state. These favorable conditions have not yet been met in conjugated materials and set the stage for further developments in this area.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXotFagtLc%253D&md5=9ab73c603f1d3e0e7e559b95997fa33c
        open URL
      43. 43
        Marcus, R. A. Electron Transfer Reactions in Chemistry. Theory and Experiment. Rev. Mod. Phys. 1993, 65, 599– 610,  DOI: 10.1103/RevModPhys.65.599
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        43
        Electron transfer reactions in chemistry. Theory and experiment
        Marcus, Rudolph A.
        Reviews of Modern Physics (1993), 65 (3, Pt. 1), 599-610CODEN: RMPHAT; ISSN:0034-6861.
        A review with many refs. Since the late 1940s, the field of electron transfer processes has grown enormously, both in chem. and biol. The development of the field, exptl. and theor., as well as its relation to the study of other kinds of chem. reactions, represents an intriguing history, one in which many threads have been brought together. History, recent trends, and the author's research are described.

      45. 45
        Gray, H. B.; Winkler, J. R. Electron Flow Through Proteins. Chem. Phys. Lett. 2009, 483, 1– 9,  DOI: 10.1016/j.cplett.2009.10.051
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        45
        Electron flow through proteins
        Gray, Harry B.; Winkler, Jay R.
        Chemical Physics Letters (2009), 483 (1-3), 1-9CODEN: CHPLBC; ISSN:0009-2614. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. Electron transfers in photosynthesis and respiration commonly occur between metal-contg. cofactors that are sepd. by large mol. distances. Employing laser flash-quench triggering methods, we have shown that 20-Å, coupling-limited FeII-RuIII and CuI-RuIII electron tunneling in Ru-modified cytochromes and blue copper proteins can occur on the microsecond timescale both in solns. and crystals. Redox equiv. can be transferred even longer distances by multistep tunneling, often called hopping, through intervening amino acid side chains. Our work has established that 20-Å hole hopping through an intervening tryptophan is two orders of magnitude faster than single-step electron tunneling in a Re-modified blue copper protein.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsVaisb%252FI&md5=63795567968b1c92b1876be3d8820d76
        open URL
      46. 46
        Yin, S.; Li, L.; Yang, Y.; Reimers, J. R. Challenges for the accurate simulation of anisotropic charge mobilities through organic molecular crystals: The β phase of mer-tris (8-hydroxyquinolinato) aluminum (III)(Alq3) crystal. J. Phys. Chem. C 2012, 116, 14826– 14836,  DOI: 10.1021/jp303724r
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        46
        Challenges for the Accurate Simulation of Anisotropic Charge Mobilities through Organic Molecular Crystals: The β Phase of mer-Tris(8-hydroxyquinolinato)aluminum(III) (Alq3) Crystal
        Yin, Shiwei; Li, Lanlan; Yang, Yongmei; Reimers, Jeffrey R.
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2012), 116 (28), 14826-14836CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        Quant. agreement was found between obsd. and calcd. charge mobilities through org. conductors, despite the use of many assumptions in the calcns., including: the relative strength of the intermol. electronic coupling to the reorganization energy driving charge localization, the treatment of site variability in the material, the involvement of tunneling processes during charge hopping between sites, the use of weak-coupling-based perturbation theory to det. hopping rates, the residence times for charges on sites, the effect of the large field strengths used in exptl. studies, the general appropriateness of simple 1-dimensional diffusion modeling approaches, and the involvement of mol. excited states of the ions. The authors study the impact of these assumptions, concluding that all may be very significant. In some cases, methodol. options are considered, and optimum procedures are detd., showing that (i) the use of Koopmans' theorem to est. intermol. couplings in solids is problematic and (ii) the correct expression for the residence lifetime of a charge on a crystal site. These conclusions are drawn from simulations of anisotropic charge mobilities through the β phase of mer-tris(8-hydroxyquinolinato)aluminum(III) (Alq3) crystal, a material commonly used in OLED applications. Calcns. are compared that det. mobilities at finite applied field from drift velocities through either semianal. solns. of the master equation or else kinetic Monte Carlo simulations, as well as those that det. mobilities from multidimensional diffusion coeffs. at zero field by Monte Carlo and those that anal. solve simplified 1-dimensional diffusion models. For cryst. Alq3 itself, the calcns. predict electron mobilities that are 4-6 orders of magnitude larger than those predicted by similar methods for amorphous Alq3, in agreement with exptl. findings. This work vindicates recent theories describing the poor mobilities of the amorphous material, forming a complete basic picture for Alq3 cond.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XosFekur4%253D&md5=e31d954519b707956185a6ec96fc0225
        open URL

        Lee, C.; Yang, W.; Parr, R. G. Development of the Colle-Salvetti correlation-energy formula into a functional of the electron density. Phys. Rev. B 1988, 37, 785,  DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevB.37.785
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        48
        Development of the Colle-Salvetti correlation-energy formula into a functional of the electron density
        Lee, Chengteh; Yang, Weitao; Parr, Robert G.
        Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics (1988), 37 (2), 785-9CODEN: PRBMDO; ISSN:0163-1829.
        A correlation-energy formula due to R. Colle and D. Salvetti (1975), in which the correlation energy d. is expressed in terms of the electron d. and a Laplacian of the 2nd-order Hartree-Fock d. matrix, is restated as a formula involving the d. and local kinetic-energy d. On insertion of gradient expansions for the local kinetic-energy d., d.-functional formulas for the correlation energy and correlation potential are then obtained. Through numerical calcns. on a no. of atoms, pos. ions, and mols., of both open- and closed-shell type, it is demonstrated that these formulas, like the original Colle-Salvetti formulas, give correlation energies within a few percent.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1cXktFWrtbw%253D&md5=ee7b59267a2ff72e15171a481819ccf8
        open URL

        Tai, C.-K.; Hsieh, C.-A.; Hsiao, K.-L.; Wang, B.-C.; Wei, Y. Novel Dipolar 5,5,10,10-Tetraphenyl-5,10-ihydroindeno[2,1-a]-indene Derivatives for SM-OPV:A Combined Theoretical and Experimental Study. Org. Electron. 2015, 16, 54– 70,  DOI: 10.1016/j.orgel.2014.10.031
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        49
        Novel dipolar 5,5,10,10-tetraphenyl-5,10-dihydroindeno[2,1-a]-indene derivatives for SM-OPV: A combined theoretical and experimental study
        Tai, Chin-Kuen; Hsieh, Chun-An; Hsiao, Kai-Lun; Wang, Bo-Cheng; Wei, Yi
        Organic Electronics (2015), 16 (), 54-70CODEN: OERLAU; ISSN:1566-1199. (Elsevier B.V.)
        In order to investigate the photo-phys., electrochem., and optoelectronic properties of dipolar 5,5,10,10-tetraphenyl-5,10-dihydroindeno[2,1-a]-indene (TDI) derivs., a facile synthesis has been developed to integrate arylamine (electron donor fragment, D) and aryl-2-methylenemalononitrile (electron acceptor fragment, A) into the TDI bridge. According to calcn. results using the DFT/B3LYP/6-31G(d) method, the HOMO and LUMO energies of TDI derivs. are relevant to the extent of corresponding electron donating and accepting abilities and influence the open-circuit voltage (Voc) and driving force (ΔE) in org. photovoltaics (OPV). The projected d. of state (pDOS) anal. shows that the electron d. distribution from the D fragment to TDI bridge in the HOMO is attributing to the electron-donating ability, whereas the electrons are mainly localized on A fragment in the LUMO. Calcns. of the reorganization energy by the DFT/B3LYP/6-31G(d) method suggest these D-TDI-A derivs. are hole-transporting type materials. On the other hand, the calcd. absorption spectra for these mols. in CH2Cl2 are simulated by using the TD-DFT/BH and HLYP/6-31G(d) method within the Polarizable Continuum Model (PCM) and provide the max. absorption wavelength (λmax), which can be assigned to the HOMO to LUMO transition. HOMO is found to be the π orbital which is delocalized between the D fragment and the π-linker and LUMO is the π* orbital which is concd. on the A fragment. The optical properties of D-TDI-A derivs. can be influenced by the D fragment and π-conjugated length. Calcd. results of D-TDI-A derivs. also exhibited a large light harvesting efficiency related to the max. absorption wavelength (RLHE) and according to these results, the D-TDI-A derivs. contg. the Ab and Ad fragments would be useful electron donor materials for further development of new small mol. org. photovoltaic solar cell (SM-OPV) devices.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhvFSmurbJ&md5=70e9075a525c9aa66ea2ff5c1d121a70

        Theoretical design of thiazolothiazole-based organic dyes with different electron donors for dye-sensitized solar cells
        Fitri, Asmae; Benjelloun, Adil Touimi; Benzakour, Mohammed; McHarfi, Mohammed; Hamidi, Mohammed; Bouachrine, Mohammed
        Spectrochimica Acta, Part A: Molecular and Biomolecular Spectroscopy (2014), 132 (), 232-238CODEN: SAMCAS; ISSN:1386-1425. (Elsevier B.V.)
        In this study, we have designed four novel org. donor-π-acceptor dyes (D1, D2, D3, D4), used for dye-sensitized solar cells. The electron acceptor (anchoring) group was 2-cyanoacrylic for all dyes whereas the electron donor unit varied (coumarin, indoline, carbazole, triphenylamine) and the influence was investigated. These dyes, based on thiazolothiazole as π-spacer, were studied by d. functional theory (DFT) and its extensible time-dependent DFT approaches to shed light on how the π-conjugation order influences the performance of the dyes in the dye-sensitized solar cells. The theor. results have shown that the LUMO and HOMO energy levels of these dyes can be ensuring pos. effect on the process of electron injection and dye regeneration. The trend of the calcd. HOMO-LUMO gaps nicely compares with the spectral data. Key parameters in close connection with the short-circuit c.d., including light harvesting efficiency, injection driving force (ΔGinject.) and total reorganization energy (λtotal), were discussed. The calcd. results of these dyes reveal that dye D2, with indoline as electron donor group, can be used as a potential sensitizer for TiO2 nanocryst. solar cells due to its best electronic and optical properties and good photovoltaic parameters.

        Bérubé, N.; Gosselin, V.; Gaudreau, J.; Cote, M. Designing Polymers for Photovoltaic Applications Using Ab Initio Calculations. J. Phys. Chem. C 2013, 117, 7964– 7972,  DOI: 10.1021/jp309800f
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        52
        Designing polymers for photovoltaic applications using ab initio calculations
        Berube, Nicolas; Gosselin, Vincent; Gaudreau, Josiane; Cote, Michel
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2013), 117 (16), 7964-7972CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        This article evaluates the efficiency of d. functional theory calcns. when used in conjunction with Scharber's model to predict the power conversion efficiency of org. solar cells. Thirty polymers were investigated, and their calcd. electronic properties were assessed against their reported exptl. values. The energy level calcns. have a relatively small std. deviation of about 0.2 eV after a correction for a systematic overestimation. The optical band gap and the open-circuit voltage are obtained within an accuracy of 0.09 eV and 0.10 V, resp. Also, the model provides an indication of the max. value for the short-circuit current and an interesting guiding tool to identify promising suitable polymers to reach high power conversion efficiencies. After validating the present numerical approach against known devices, new polymers that could reach a power conversion efficiency ranging from 8 to 11% are presented.

        Sharma, G.; Shanap, T.; Patel, K.; El-Mansy, M. Photovoltaic Properties of Bulk Heterojunction Devices Based on CuI-PVA as Electron Donor and PCBM and Modified PCBM as Electron Acceptor. Mater. Sci.-Pol. 2012, 30, 10– 16,  DOI: 10.2478/s13536-012-0003-6
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        53
        Photovoltaic properties of bulk heterojunction devices based on CuI-PVA as electron donor and PCBM and modified PCBM as electron acceptor
        Sharma, G. D.; Shanap, T. S.; Patel, K. R.; El-Mansy, M. K.
        Materials Science-Poland (2012), 30 (1), 10-16CODEN: MSACDV; ISSN:2083-134X. (Versita)
        In this paper, we have investigated the bulk heterojunction org. solar cells based on CuI - polyvinyl alc. (CuI-PVA) nanocomposite as electron donor and [6,6] - Ph C60 - butyric acid Me ester (PCBM) or modified PCBM i.e. F as electron acceptor. The power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) of 0.46 % and 0.68 % were achieved for the photovoltaic devices based on as cast CuI-PVA:PCBM and CuI-PVA:F blend films, resp. The higher PCEs of the org. solar cells based on F as electron acceptor resulted from the increase in both short circuit current (Jsc) and open circuit voltage (Voc), due to the increased absorption of F in visible region and its higher LUMO level. After thermal annealing, the PCEs of the org. solar cells were further increased to 0.54 % and 0.80 % for CuI-PVA:PCBM and CuI-PVA:F blends, resp. The increase in the PCEs was mainly due to the increase in Jsc, which has been attributed to the improvement in hole mobility and broadening of the absorption band in the longer wavelength region. The improved hole mobility resulted in more balanced charge transport in the devices based on the thermally annealed blends.

        Influence of blend microstructure on bulk heterojunction organic photovoltaic performance
        Brabec, Christoph J.; Heeney, Martin; McCulloch, Iain; Nelson, Jenny
        Chemical Society Reviews (2011), 40 (3), 1185-1199CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. The performance of org. photovoltaic devices based upon bulk heterojunction blends of donor and acceptor materials has been shown to be highly dependent on the thin film microstructure. In this tutorial review, we discuss the factors responsible for influencing blend microstructure and how these affect device performance. In particular we discuss how various mol. design approaches can affect the thin film morphol. of both the donor and acceptor components, as well as their blend microstructure. We further examine the influence of polymer mol. wt. and blend compn. on device performance, and discuss how a variety of processing techniques can be used to control the blend microstructure, leading to improvements in solar cell efficiencies.

        Organic molecules based on dithienyl-2,1,3-benzothiadiazole as new donor materials for solution-processed organic photovoltaic cells
        Wu, Zhong-Lian; Fan, Ben-Hu; Xue, Feng; Adachi, Chihaya; Ouyang, Jian-Yong
        Solar Energy Materials & Solar Cells (2010), 94 (12), 2230-2237CODEN: SEMCEQ; ISSN:0927-0248. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Polymers based on dithienyl-2,1,3-benzothiadiazole (TBT) have received strong attention as the donor materials of polymer photovoltaic cells (PVs), since they can have a low band gap. But sol. small org. mols. based on TBT have been rarely studied. This paper reports the synthesis of two small org. mols. based on TBT and their application as the donor materials of soln.-processed bulk heterojunction org. photovoltaic cells (OPVs). These compds. were sol. in common org. solvents, such as chloroform, chlorobenzene and THF. They have band gaps comparable to poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT) and lower HOMO and LUMO (HOMO:HOMO, LUMO:LUMO) levels than P3HT. These mols. and [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid Me ester (PCBM) were used as the donors and acceptor to fabricate bulk heterojunction OPVs through soln. processing. After optimization of the exptl. conditions, power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 0.66% was achieved on the soln.-processed OPVs under AM 1.5G, 100 mW/cm-2 illumination.

        Unified assay of adverse effects from the varied nanoparticle hybrid in polymer-fullerene organic photovoltaics
        Huang, Yu-Jui; Lo, Wei-Chun; Liu, Shun-Wei; Cheng, Chao-Han; Chen, Chin-Ti; Wang, Juen-Kai
        Solar Energy Materials & Solar Cells (2013), 116 (), 153-170CODEN: SEMCEQ; ISSN:0927-0248. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Nanoparticles (NPs) having different surface capping agent, variant elec. cond. and sunlight absorption have been studied for the ternary hybrid contg. poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT) and [6,6]-phenyl-C-61-butyric acid Me ester (PCBM) in bulk heterojunction (BHJ) org. photovoltaics (OPVs). These NPs are composed of conducting gold, semiconducting CdS or PbS, or insulating cage-like mol. silica (POSS). We use a series of microscopic methods including TEM, AFM, SEM, optical, and fluorescence microscopy to est. NP size and to probe the agglomeration and/or aggregation of NPs in P3HT/PCBM blends. Surface capping agent arom. thiophenol (SPh) was found to be poor in the dispersion of NPs in P3HT/PCBM blends. The light harvesting of these NPs ranges from transparent (POSS NP), near transparent (CdS NP), visible light absorbing (Au NP), to near-IR absorbing (PbS NP). Nevertheless, the absorbance of these NPs is all too small relative to that of P3HT polymer. Concerning the charge sepn. of P3HT exciton, the LUMO energy levels of these NPs have been detd. by the combination of optical band-gap energy and HOMO energy levels. By the transient photocurrent time-of-flight method, charge carrier mobility of P3HT/PCBM/NP(CdS-SPh) ternary hybrid was found to be improved, although fluorescence quenching studies imply insufficient or ineffective contact between P3HT and all NPs in the present study. NPs hybrid P3HT/PCBM BHJ OPVs were fabricated by soln. process. Regardless of cond. or sunlight absorbance, all NPs show no improvement on power conversion efficiency of ternary hybrid OPVs, which is 3.03-3.91% less than 4.0-4.1% of P3HT/PCBM OPVs without NPs. Based on the present study, a few problems that assoc. with the inferior performance of NPs hybrid P3HT/PCBM BHJ OPVs are delineated.

        Zhang, X.; Li, X.-D.; Ma, L.-X.; Zhang, B. Electronic and Electrochemical Properties as Well as Flowerlike Supramolecular Assemblies of Fulleropyrrolidines Bearing Ester Substituents with Different Alkyl Chain Lengths. RSC Adv. 2014, 4, 60342– 60348,  DOI: 10.1039/C4RA10654G

        Electronic and electrochemical properties as well as flowerlike supramolecular assemblies of fulleropyrrolidines bearing ester substituents with different alkyl chain lengths
        Zhang, Xuan; Li, Xu-Dong; Ma, Li-Xia; Zhang, Bei
        RSC Advances (2014), 4 (104), 60342-60348CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A series of alkyl (Me, Et, Pr, butyl) benzoate ester substituted fulleropyrrolidine derivs. (FP1-FP4) were synthesized and their electronic and electrochem. properties were investigated by means of absorption spectra, electronic structure calcn. and cyclic voltammetry (CV), resp. The LUMO-HOMO energies and energy gaps of fullerene derivs. were estd. by the first redn. potential measured with CV combined with absorption spectra, which are consistent with those obtained from d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. It was found that all fulleropyrrolidines showed very similar absorption spectra, orbital energies and redox behaviors, which are comparable with those of well-known phenyl-C61-butyric acid Me ester (PCBM). The flowerlike supramol. architectures obtained from the self-assembly of FP1-FP4 in chloroform-alc. mixt. solvents were characterized by SEM and X-ray diffraction (XRD). A lamellar structure with a d-spacing of 1.92-2.02 nm that depends on the mol. size, corresponding to the thickness of a bilayer structure, suggested a face-to-face conformation of the substituent of C60 and an interdigitation of the bare C60 side packing. These fulleropyrrolidines have high C60 content, are energetically PCBM-like, and are capable of forming complex flowerlike architectures, which provide fundamental insights into mol. design toward advanced fullerene materials.

      59. 59
        Yoo, S. H.; Kum, J. M.; Cho, S. O. Tuning the electronic band structure of PCBM by electron irradiation. Nanoscale Res. Lett. 2011, 6, 545  DOI: 10.1186/1556-276X-6-545
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        59
        Tuning the electronic band structure of PCBM by electron irradiation
        Yoo, Seung Hwa; Kum, Jong Min; Cho, Sung Oh
        Nanoscale Research Letters (2011), 6 (1), 545/1-545/7CODEN: NRLAAD; ISSN:1556-276X. (Springer)
        Tuning the electronic band structures such as band-edge position and bandgap of org. semiconductors is crucial to maximize the performance of org. photovoltaic devices. We present a simple yet effective electron irradn. approach to tune the band structure of [6, 6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid Me ester (PCBM) that is the most widely used org. acceptor material. We have found that the LUMO (LUMO) level of PCBM up-shifts toward the vacuum energy level, while the HOMO (HOMO) level down-shifts when PCBM is electron-irradiated. The shift of the HOMO and the LUMO levels increases as the irradiated electron fluence increases. Accordingly, the band-edge position and the bandgap of PCBM can be controlled by adjusting the electron fluence. Characterization of electron-irradiated PCBM reveals that the variation of the band structure is attributed to the mol. structural change of PCBM by electron irradn.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Density functional theory design and characterization of D-A-A type electron donors with narrow band gap for small-molecule organic solar cells
        Wang, Dongmei; Zhang, Xinghui; Ding, Weilu; Zhao, Xiaoling; Geng, Zhiyuan
        Computational & Theoretical Chemistry (2014), 1029 (), 68-78CODEN: CTCOA5; ISSN:2210-271X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        For seeking the high-efficiency narrow-band-gap donor materials to enhance short-circuit c.d. (Jsc) for org. solar cells, a series of D-A-A type small mols. derived from the synthesized donor DTDCTB and with different heterocyclic bridges were designed and characterized by using d. functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT calcns. According to the electron-withdrawing strength of the heterocyclic bridges and mol. energy matching relationship, we designed and ultimately chose four ideal donors (3, 5, 16 and 19) which have the suitable energy levels to match with PCBM and narrower band gaps than DTDCTB. Next, the properties affecting open-circuit voltage (Voc), Jsc and fill factor (FF) were investigated by calcg. the geometrical structures, frontier MO energy levels, absorption spectra, light harvesting efficiencies, chare-transfer indexes, exciton binding energies and hole mobilities of the ideal donors, as well as DTDCTB for comparison. The results show that 3 has lower HOMO level, higher absorption efficiency, more favorable exciton dissocn. and hole transport than others, facilitating the improvement of the Voc, Jsc and FF. Finally, 3 would be the most promising one in this series of donors and further boost the device efficiency.

        Optimization of energy levels by molecular design: evaluation of bis-diketopyrrolopyrrole molecular donor materials for bulk heterojunction solar cells
        Walker, Bright; Liu, Jianhua; Kim, Chunki; Welch, Gregory C.; Park, Jin Keun; Lin, Jason; Zalar, Peter; Proctor, Christopher M.; Seo, Jung Hwa; Bazan, Guillermo C.; Nguyen, Thuc-Quyen
        Energy & Environmental Science (2013), 6 (3), 952-962CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        We report a series of soln.-processable, small-mol., donor materials based on an architecture consisting of two diketopyrrolopyrrole (DPP) cores with different arom. π-bridges between the DPP units and different end-capping groups. In general, this architecture leads to desirable light absorption and electronic levels for donor materials. Out of the compds. investigated, a material with a hydrolyzed dithieno[3,2-b;2',3'-d]silole (SDT) core and 2-benzofuran (BFu) end capping groups leads to the most favorable properties for solar cells, capable of generating photocurrent up to 800 nm while producing an open-circuit voltage of over 850 mV, indicating a small loss in elec. potential compared to other bulk heterojunction systems. Device properties can be greatly improved through the use of solvent additives such as 2-chloronaphthalene and initial attempts to optimize device fabrication have resulted in power conversion efficiencies upwards of 4%.
