        Theoretical characterization and design of small molecule donor material containing naphthodithiophene central unit for efficient organic solar cells
        Duan, Yu-Ai; Geng, Yun; Li, Hai-Bin; Jin, Jun-Ling; Wu, Yong; Su, Zhong-Min
        Journal of Computational Chemistry (2013), 34 (19), 1611-1619CODEN: JCCHDD; ISSN:0192-8651. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
        To seek for high-performance small mol. donor materials used in heterojunction solar cell, six acceptor-donor-acceptor small mols. based on naphtho[2,3-b:6,7-b']dithiophene (NDT) units with different acceptor units were designed and characterized using d. functional theory and time-dependent d. functional theory. Their geometries, electronic structures, photophys., and charge transport properties have been scrutinized comparing with the reported donor material NDT(TDPP)2 (TDPP = thiophene-capped diketopyrrolopyrrole). The open circuit voltage (Voc), energetic driving force(ΔEL-L), and exciton binding energy (Eb) were also provided to give an elementary understanding on their cell performance. The results reveal that the frontier MOs of 3-7 match well with the acceptor material PC61BM, and compds. 3-5 were found to exhibit the comparable performances to 1 and show promising potential in org. solar cells. In particular, comparing with 1, system 7 with naphthobisthiadiazole acceptor unit displays broader absorption spectrum, higher Voc, lower Eb, and similar carrier mobility. An in-depth insight into the nature of the involved excited states based on transition d. matrix and charge d. difference indicates that all S1 states are mainly intramol. charge transfer states with the charge transfer from central NDT unit to bilateral acceptor units, and also imply that the exciton of 7 can be dissocd. easily due to its large extent of the charge transfer. In a word, 7 maybe superior to 1 and may act as a promising donor candidate for org. solar cell.

        63
        The future of organic photovoltaics
        Mazzio, Katherine A.; Luscombe, Christine K.
        Chemical Society Reviews (2015), 44 (1), 78-90CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Increasing global demand for energy, along with dwindling fossil fuel resources and a better understanding of the hidden costs assocd. with these energy sources, have spurred substantial political, academic, and industrial interest in alternative energy resources. Photovoltaics based on org. semiconductors have emerged as promising low-cost alternatives for electricity generation that relies on sunlight. In this tutorial review we discuss the relevance of these org. photovoltaics beginning with some of the economic drivers for these technologies. We then examine the basic properties of these devices, including operation and materials requirements, in addn. to presenting the development of the field from a historical perspective. Potential future directions are also briefly discussed. This tutorial review is intended to be an essential overview of the progress of the field, in addn. to aiding in the discussion of the future of OPV technologies.

        Charge generation in polymer-fullerene bulk-heterojunction solar cells
        Gao, Feng; Inganaes, Olle
        Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2014), 16 (38), 20291-20304CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Charge generation in org. solar cells is a fundamental yet heavily debated issue. This article gives a balanced review of different mechanisms proposed to explain efficient charge generation in polymer-fullerene bulk-heterojunction solar cells. The effect is discussed of charge-transfer states, excess energy, external elec. field, temp., disorder of the materials, and delocalization of the charge carriers on charge generation. Although a general consensus has not been reached yet, recent findings, based on both steady-state and transient measurements, have significantly advanced the understanding of this process.

        Zheng, Z.; Bredas, J.-L.; Coropceanu, V. Description of the Charge Transfer States at the Pentacene/C60 Interface: Combining Range-Separated Hybrid Functionals with the Polarizable Continuum Model. J. Phys. Chem. Lett. 2016, 7, 2616– 2621,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpclett.6b00911
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        66
        Description of the Charge Transfer States at the Pentacene/C60 Interface: Combining Range-Separated Hybrid Functionals with the Polarizable Continuum Model
        Zheng, Zilong; Bredas, Jean-Luc; Coropceanu, Veaceslav
        Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters (2016), 7 (13), 2616-2621CODEN: JPCLCD; ISSN:1948-7185. (American Chemical Society)
        D. functional theory (DFT) approaches based on range-sepd. hybrid functionals are currently methods of choice for the description of the charge-transfer (CT) states in org. donor/acceptor solar cells. However, these calcns. are usually performed on small-size donor/acceptor complexes and as result do not account for electronic polarization effects. Here, using a pentacene/C60 complex as a model system, we discuss the ability of long-range cor. (LCR) hybrid functionals in combination with the polarizable continuum model (PCM) to det. the impact of the solid-state environment on the CT states. The CT energies are found to be insensitive to the interactions with the dielec. medium when a conventional time-dependent DFT/PCM (TDDFT/PCM) approach is used. However, a decrease in the energy of the CT state in the framework of LRC functionals can be obtained by using a smaller range-sepd. parameter when going from an isolated donor/acceptor complex to the solid-state case.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtVCjt7%252FK&md5=2fea6e077388e6d847990d3e69c00899
        open URL

        Mangaud, E.; Meier, C.; Desouter-Lecomte, M. Analysis of the Non-Markovianity for Electron Transfer Reactions in an Oligothiophene-Fullerene Heterojunction. Chem. Phys. 2017, 494, 90– 102,  DOI: 10.1016/j.chemphys.2017.07.011
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        67
        Analysis of the non-Markovianity for electron transfer reactions in an oligothiophene-fullerene heterojunction
        Mangaud, E.; Meier, C.; Desouter-Lecomte, M.
        Chemical Physics (2017), 494 (), 90-102CODEN: CMPHC2; ISSN:0301-0104. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The non-Markovianity of the electron transfer in an oligothiophene-fullerene heterojunction described by a spin-boson model is analyzed using the time dependent decoherence canonical rates and the vol. of accessible states in the Bloch sphere. The dynamical map of the reduced electronic system is computed by the hierarchical equations of motion methodol. (HEOM) providing an exact dynamics. Transitory witness of non-Markovianity is linked to the bath dynamics analyzed from the HEOM auxiliary matrixes. The signature of the collective bath mode detected from HEOM in each electronic state is compared with predictions of the effective mode extd. from the spectral d. We show that including this main reaction coordinate in a one-dimensional vibronic system coupled to a residual bath satisfactorily describes the electron transfer by a simple Markovian Redfield equation. Non-Markovianity is computed for three inter fragment distances and compared with a priori criterion based on the system and bath characteristic timescales.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtlartrbL&md5=fe50d3729675d55958f6b76e095328d8
        open URL
      68. 68
        Lee, D.; Forsuelo, M. A.; Kocherzhenko, A. A.; Whaley, K. B. Higher-Energy Charge Transfer States Facilitate Charge Separation in Donor–Acceptor Molecular Dyads. J. Phys. Chem. C 2017, 121, 13043– 13051,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpcc.7b03197
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        68
        Higher-Energy Charge Transfer States Facilitate Charge Separation in Donor-Acceptor Molecular Dyads
        Lee, Donghyun; Forsuelo, Michael A.; Kocherzhenko, Aleksey A.; Whaley, K. Birgitta
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2017), 121 (24), 13043-13051CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        We simulate sub-picosecond charge sepn. in two donor-acceptor mol. dyads. Charge sepn. dynamics is described using a quantum master equation, with parameters of the dyad Hamiltonian obtained from d. functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent d. functional theory (TDDFT) calcns., and the rate of energy dissipation estd. from Ehrenfest-TDDFT mol. dynamics simulations. We find that higher-energy charge transfer states must be included in the dyad Hamiltonian in order to obtain agreement of charge sepn. rates with the exptl. values. Our results show that efficient and irreversible charge sepn. involves both coherent electron transfer from the donor excited state to higher-energy unoccupied states on the acceptor and incoherent energy dissipation that relaxes the dyad to the lowest energy charge transfer state. The role of coherence depends on the initial excited state, with electron delocalization within Hamiltonian eigenstates found to be more important than coherence between eigenstates. We conclude that ultrafast charge sepn. is most likely to occur in donor-acceptor dyads possessing dense manifolds of charge transfer states at energies close to those of Frenkel excitons on the donor, with strong couplings to these states enabling partial delocalization of eigenstates over acceptor and donor.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXotVGqtL8%253D&md5=d7fe3e5371f8ed09b7a57ae8963a6f04
        open URL

        Design rules for donors in bulk-heterojunction solar cells-towards 10 % energy-conversion efficiency
        Scharber, Markus C.; Muehlbacher, David; Koppe, Markus; Denk, Patrick; Waldauf, Christoph; Heeger, Alan J.; Brabec, Christoph J.

        Solar cells were fabricated from a variety of com. available compds. and were studied. A linear relation between Voc and the oxidn. potential is found (see figure). Based on this relation, the energy-conversion efficiency of a bulk-heterojunction solar cell is derived as a function of the bandgap and the energy levels of the conjugated polymer.

        Guo, X.; Zhang, M.; Huo, L.; Cui, C.; Wu, Y.; Hou, J.; Li, Y. Poly(thieno [3, 2-b]Thiophene-alt-bithiazole): A–D–A Copolymer Donor Showing Improved Photovoltaic Performance with Indene-C60 Bisadduct Acceptor. Macromolecules 2012, 45, 6930– 6937,  DOI: 10.1021/ma301269f

        73
        Poly(thieno[3,2-b]thiophene-alt-bithiazole): A D-A Copolymer Donor Showing Improved Photovoltaic Performance with Indene-C60 Bisadduct Acceptor
        Guo, Xia; Zhang, Maojie; Huo, Lijun; Cui, Chaohua; Wu, Yue; Hou, Jianhui; Li, Yongfang
        Macromolecules (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 45 (17), 6930-6937CODEN: MAMOBX; ISSN:0024-9297. (American Chemical Society)
        A new D-A copolymer, poly(thieno[3,2-b]thiophene-alt-bithiazole) (PTTBTz), based on thieno[3,2-b]thiophene donor unit and bithiazole acceptor unit, was synthesized by the Pd-catalyzed Stille-coupling reaction for the application as donor material in polymer solar cells (PSCs). PTTBTz film possesses high thermal stability with 5% wt.-loss temp. at 450 °, a lower-lying HOMO energy level at -5.20 eV, a higher hole mobility of 6.45 × 10-3 cm2/(V s), and a cryst. structure. Photovoltaic performance of the polymer was investigated with [6,6]-phenyl-C71-butyric acid Me ester (PC70BM) or indene-C60 bisadduct (ICBA) as acceptor and with 3% DIO additive. The power conversion efficiency (PCE) of the PSC based on PTTBTz:ICBA (1:1 wt./wt.) reached 5.35% with a high Voc of 1.03 V, a Jsc of 8.55 mA/cm2, and an FF of 0.608, whereas the PCE of the PSC based on PTTBTz:PC70BM (1:1 wt./wt.) was 4.57% with a Voc of 0.82 V, a Jsc of 9.89 mA/cm2, and an FF of 0.563, under the illumination of AM1.5, 100 mW/cm2. PTTBTz is one of the D-A copolymers that shows better photovoltaic performance with ICBA as acceptor than PC70BM. PTTBTz/ICBA could be a promising front active layer for high-efficiency tandem PSC because of its high Voc.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xht1ektrzF&md5=dc9c680f1821d992e79afe4477753a0f

      74. 74
        Nayak, P. K.; Garcia-Belmonte, G.; Kahn, A.; Bisquert, J.; Cahen, D. Photovoltaic Efficiency Limits and Material Disorder. Energy Environ. Sci. 2012, 5, 6022– 6039,  DOI: 10.1039/c2ee03178g
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        74
        Photovoltaic efficiency limits and material disorder
        Nayak, Pabitra K.; Garcia-Belmonte, Germa; Kahn, Antoine; Bisquert, Juan; Cahen, David
        Energy & Environmental Science (2012), 5 (3), 6022-6039CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Solar cells based on cryst. semiconductors such as Si and GaAs provide nowadays the highest performance, but photovoltaic (PV) cells based on less pure materials, such as poly- or nano-cryst. or amorphous inorg. or org. materials, or a combination of these, should relax prodn. requirements and lower the cost towards reliable, sustainable and economic elec. power from sunlight. So as to be able to compare the operation of different classes of solar cells we first summarize general photovoltaic principles and then consider implications of using less than ideal materials. In general, lower material purity means more disorder, which introduces a broad distribution of energy states of the electronic carriers that affects all the aspects of PV performance, from light absorption to the generation of voltage and current. Specifically, disorder penalizes energy output by enhanced recombination, with respect to the radiative limit, and also imposes a lowering of quasi-Fermi levels into the gap, which decreases their sepn., i.e., reduces the photovoltage. In solar cells based on org. absorbers, such as dye-sensitized or bulk heterojunction solar cells, vibronic effects cause relaxation of carriers in the absorber, which implies an energy price in terms of obtainable output.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XivFWntLc%253D&md5=ee1a89624da5fe0364d5bf8e1081d8a9
        open URL
      75. 75
        Green, M. A. Accuracy of Analytical Expressions for Solar Cell Fill Factors. Sol. Cells 1982, 7, 337– 340,  DOI: 10.1016/0379-6787(82)90057-6
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        75
        Accuracy of analytical expressions for solar cell fill factors
        Green, Martin A.
        Solar Cells (1982), 7 (3), 337-40CODEN: SOCLD4; ISSN:0379-6787.
        Although the fill factor of a solar cell is a useful parameter in characterizing the cell performance, it cannot be expressed explicitly in terms of other cell parameters. The accuracy of previously published and new anal. approxns. for this factor are compared and the most useful expressions are summarized, including the effects of temp., ideality factor, and series and shunt parasitic resistances.

        Single-Junction Organic Solar Cells Based on a Novel Wide-Bandgap Polymer with Efficiency of 9.7%
        Huo, Lijun; Liu, Tao; Sun, Xiaobo; Cai, Yunhao; Heeger, Alan J.; Sun, Yanming
        Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2015), 27 (18), 2938-2944CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A novel DTBDT-based wide-bandgap (WBG) polymer, PDBT-T1, was developed and applied in org. solar cells. Primary optimization of PDBT-T1/C70BM wt. ratios yielded PCE = 8.35%. Solar cells processed with 0.5% vol./vol. 1,8-diiodooctane exhibit a significant increase in FF (up to 75%), leading to an impressive PCE = 9.74%, which is the highest PCE reported for WBG polymers-based single-junction org. solar cells and among the highest values reported for org. solar cell system so far. This high efficiency is attributed to efficient photogenerated exciton dissocn. and charge collection in devices. The comprehensive high photovoltaic performance of PDBT-T1 makes it an outstanding candidate as a WBG material for tandem (or multi-junction) org. solar cells.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXls1eht7o%253D&md5=53cb6d130200cd8d54dcf1f3f48724bb
        open URL
      77. 77
        Trukhanov, V. A.; Bruevich, V. V.; Paraschuk, D. Y. Fill factor in Organic Solar Cells Can Exceed the Shockley-Queisser Limit. Sci. Rep. 2015, 5, 11478  DOI: 10.1038/srep11478
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        77
        Fill factor in organic solar cells can exceed the Shockley-Queisser limit
        Trukhanov, Vasily A.; Bruevich, Vladimir V.; Paraschuk, Dmitry Yu.
        Scientific Reports (2015), 5 (), 11478CODEN: SRCEC3; ISSN:2045-2322. (Nature Publishing Group)
        The ultimate efficiency of org. solar cells (OSC) is under active debate. The solar cell efficiency is calcd. from the current-voltage characteristic as a product of the open-circuit voltage (VOC), short-circuit current (JSC), and the fill factor (FF). While the factors limiting VOC and JSC for OSC were extensively studied, the ultimate FF for OSC is scarcely explored. Using numerical drift-diffusion modeling, we have found that the FF in OSC can exceed the Shockley-Queisser limit (SQL) established for inorg. p-n junction solar cells. Comparing charge generation and recombination in org. donor-acceptor bilayer heterojunction and inorg. p-n junction, we show that such distinctive properties of OSC as interface charge generation and heterojunction facilitate high FF, but the necessary condition for FF exceeding the SQL in OSC is field-dependence of charge recombination at the donor-acceptor interface. These findings can serve as a guideline for further improvement of OSC.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtFyhsLbP&md5=da6e3064a9b350322d5eb6952c315fdd
        open URL
      78. 78
        Hou, J.; Chen, H.-Y.; Zhang, S.; Li, G.; Yang, Y. Synthesis, Characterization, and Photovoltaic Properties of a Low Band Gap Polymer Based on Silole-Containing Polythiophenes and 2, 1, 3-benzothiadiazole. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130, 16144– 16145,  DOI: 10.1021/ja806687u
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        78
        Synthesis, Characterization, and Photovoltaic Properties of a Low Band Gap Polymer Based on Silole-Containing Polythiophenes and 2,1,3-Benzothiadiazole
        Hou, Jianhui; Chen, Hsiang-Yu; Zhang, Shaoqing; Li, Gang; Yang, Yang
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (48), 16144-16145CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A new low band gap silole-contg. conjugated polymer, PSBTBT, was designed and synthesized. Photovoltaic properties of PSBTBT were initially investigated, and an av. power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 4.7%, with the highest PCE of 5.1%, was recorded under illumination (air-mass 1.5G, 100 mW/cm2). The response range of the device covers the whole visible range from 380 to 800 nm. These results indicate that PSBTBT is a promising polymer material for applications in polymer solar cells.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

      79. 79
        Scharber, M. C.; Sariciftci, N. S. Efficiency of Bulk-Heterojunction Organic Solar Cells. Prog. Polym. Sci. 2013, 38, 1929– 1940,  DOI: 10.1016/j.progpolymsci.2013.05.001
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        79
        Efficiency of bulk-heterojunction organic solar cells
        Scharber, M. C.; Sariciftci, N. S.
        Progress in Polymer Science (2013), 38 (12), 1929-1940CODEN: PRPSB8; ISSN:0079-6700. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A review. During the last years the performance of bulk heterojunction solar cells has been improved significantly. For a large-scale application of this technol. further improvements are required. This article reviews the basic working principles and the state of the art device design of bulk heterojunction solar cells. The importance of high power conversion efficiencies for the com. exploitation is outlined and different efficiency models for bulk heterojunction solar cells are discussed. Assuming state of the art materials and device architectures several models predict power conversion efficiencies in the range of 10-15%. A more general approach assuming device operation close to the Shockley-Queisser-limit leads to even higher efficiencies. Bulk heterojunction devices exhibiting only radiative recombination of charge carriers could be as efficient as ideal inorg. photovoltaic devices.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXovVWnu78%253D&md5=df14dbabab117fb4be395435e237471d

      83. 83
        Mulligan, C. J.; Wilson, M.; Bryant, G.; Vaughan, B.; Zhou, X.; Belcher, W. J.; Dastoor, P. C. A Projection of Commercial-Scale Organic Photovoltaic Module Costs. Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells 2014, 120, 9– 17,  DOI: 10.1016/j.solmat.2013.07.041
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        83
        A projection of commercial-scale organic photovoltaic module costs
        Mulligan, Cara J.; Wilson, Mitchell; Bryant, Glenn; Vaughan, Ben; Zhou, Xiaojing; Belcher, Warwick J.; Dastoor, Paul C.
        Solar Energy Materials & Solar Cells (2014), 120 (PA), 9-17CODEN: SEMCEQ; ISSN:0927-0248. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Org. photovoltaics (OPVs) are a recent technol. that has gained much attention as a potential low cost power source. Despite this promise, there is a lack of published studies that address the likely cost of com.-scale OPV modules. In this work, an engineering study est. has been performed to det. the projected cost of mass-manufd. OPV modules. The materials, prodn. capital and operating costs have been calcd. and sensitivity analyses performed to det. the parameters of greatest economic influence. Significantly, the model includes a calcn. of the costs required to establish bulk manufg. of the current high cost speciality materials components, encompassing synthesis and assocd. chem. plant design. The economic modeling reveals that the calcd. mass-manufd. OPV module costs are considerably lower than current literature ests., with OPV modules costed at $7.85 per square metre with an uncertainty of±30%. Total module cost was found to be most sensitive to the plastic substrate prices, while the prodn. rate did not have a significant impact on module cost for rates above ∼50 m2/min. The results highlight the future cost potential of OPV technol. and can be used to assist with scale-up planning.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhsFaqt7%252FM&md5=58a51116ec8863db81e5d02e5e3949bf

      84. 84
        Po, R.; Bernardi, A.; Calabrese, A.; Carbonera, C.; Corso, G.; Pellegrino, A. From Lab to Fab: How Must the Polymer Solar Cell Materials Design Change?–an Industrial Perspective. Energy Environ. Sci. 2014, 7, 925– 943,  DOI: 10.1039/c3ee43460e
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        84
        From lab to fab: how must the polymer solar cell materials design change? - an industrial perspective
        Po, Riccardo; Bernardi, Andrea; Calabrese, Anna; Carbonera, Chiara; Corso, Gianni; Pellegrino, Andrea
        Energy & Environmental Science (2014), 7 (3), 925-943CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Org. photovoltaic (OPV) devices, in particular polymer solar cells, made by soln. processed org. materials have shown great promise as a disruptive technol. for affordable electricity. Even though recent advances look impressive on paper, until now the commercialization of OPV has been hampered by the difficulty of converting lab produced "champion" cell figures into reliable industrial-scale product performances. A key factor to achieve this condition is to develop OPV materials (polymer donors, acceptors, buffer materials, electrodes materials and encapsulants) exhibiting the required tech. and economic characteristics to be conveniently used in an industrial environment. The well established strategies for the design of materials for efficient lab-scale OPV devices are not sufficient when large-area printed panels are concerned. A no. of addnl. requirements, normally not addressed in the lab. context, must be met: the materials must be easily accessible as pure compds. in few synthetic steps from cheap starting compds., need to be stable and sol. enough to afford ink formulations processable with roll-to-roll compatible equipment; solvent and solvent additives should be easily removable after printing, and possibly should be environmentally friendly compds.; the layers should achieve a stable morphol. under mild conditions (low temps. and short times); the above mentioned materials can be screened on glass substrates, but should be finally tested on plastic films, protected through a scalable encapsulation technique. The more researchers adhere to these guidelines, the greater the possibility for OPV to demonstrate at last its enormous potential on the industrial scale.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXjtlKis78%253D&md5=fe423b60e6ba84da8498c375d0605b8a
        open URL

        Poly(3-hexylthiophene): synthetic methodologies and properties in bulk heterojunction solar cells
        Marrocchi, Assunta; Lanari, Daniela; Facchetti, Antonio; Vaccaro, Luigi
        Energy & Environmental Science (2012), 5 (9), 8457-8474CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT) remains of significant importance as a prototypical benchmark hole conductor material in Org. Photovoltaics (OPVs). In this review we discuss synthetic strategies to P3HT, particularly focusing on those leading to the regioregular form and discussing key phys. and morphol. properties. Finally, a survey and a brief discussion of P3HT performance in bulk-heterojunction (BHJ) OPVs are also provided.

        Sista, P.; Ghosh, K.; Martinez, J. S.; Rocha, R. C. Polythiophenes in Biological Applications. J. Nanosci. Nanotechnol. 2014, 14, 250– 272,  DOI: 10.1166/jnn.2014.9111

        86
        Polythiophenes in biological applications
        Sista, Prakash; Ghosh, Koushik; Martinez, Jennifer S.; Rocha, Reginaldo C.
        Journal of Nanoscience and Nanotechnology (2014), 14 (1), 250-272CODEN: JNNOAR; ISSN:1533-4880. (American Scientific Publishers)
        A review. Polythiophene and its derivs. have shown tremendous potential for interfacing elec. conducting polymers with biol. applications. These semiconducting org. polymers are relatively soft, conduct electrons and ions, have low cytotoxicity, and can undergo facile chem. modifications. In addn., the redn. in elec. impedance of electrodes coated with polythiophenes may prove to be invaluable for a stable and permanent connection between devices and biol. tissues. This review article focuses on the synthesis and some key applications of polythiophenes in multidisciplinary areas at the interface with biol. These polymers have shown tremendous potential in biol. applications such as diagnostics, therapy, drug delivery, imaging, implant devices and artificial organs.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXks1Sjs78%253D&md5=71a192450daca2ead39d26fb0abdcfec

      87. 87
        Berger, P.; Kim, M. Polymer Solar Cells: P3HT:PCBM and Beyond. J. Renewable Sustainable Energy 2018, 10, 013508  DOI: 10.1063/1.5012992
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        87
        Polymer solar cells: P3HT:PCBM and beyond
        Berger, P. R.; Kim, M.
        Journal of Renewable and Sustainable Energy (2018), 10 (1), 013508/1-013508/26CODEN: JRSEBH; ISSN:1941-7012. (American Institute of Physics)
        A review. For the last two decades, polymer solar cells (PSCs) have been a cynosure of the photovoltaic community, as evidenced by the growing no. of patent applications and scientific publications. Efforts to achieve high power conversion efficiency in PSC, propelled by advances in device architecture, material combination, and nanomorphol. control, evolved into poly(3-hexylthiophene-2,5-diyl) (P3HT):phenyl-C61-Butyric-Acid-Me Ester (PCBM) bulk heterojunction PSCs, which had been the best seller in PSC research for a decade. Subsequently, PSC research was redirected towards the synthesis of low bandgap materials and optimization of tandem cells, which led to a power conversion efficiency of ∼13%. Even though this efficiency may not be sufficient enough to compete with that of inorg. solar cells, unique properties of PSCs, such as mass roll-to-roll prodn. capability, as well as flexibility and lightness, suggest their niche market opportunities. In this review, an overview of developments in PSCs is presented during the last three decades encompassing pre- and post-P3HT:PCBM era. Emphasis is given on evolution in device architecture, coupled with material selection for pre-P3HT:PCBM era, and synthesis of low-bandgap materials, coupled with a tandem structure for post-P3HT:PCBM era. Last but not least, efforts toward the longer operational lifetime of PSCs by encapsulation are reviewed. (c) 2018 American Institute of Physics.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXjtFKqs7Y%253D&md5=1acb5d5c795afebcf04ebf9e57f7ff82
        open URL

      89. 89
        Manna, A. K.; Balamurugan, D.; Cheung, M. S.; Dunietz, B. D. Unraveling the Mechanism of Photoinduced Charge Transfer in Carotenoid–Porphyrin–C60 Molecular Triad. J. Phys. Chem. Lett. 2015, 6, 1231– 1237,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpclett.5b00074
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        89
        Unraveling the Mechanism of Photoinduced Charge Transfer in Carotenoid-Porphyrin-C60 Molecular Triad
        Manna, Arun K.; Balamurugan, D.; Cheung, Margaret S.; Dunietz, Barry D.
        Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters (2015), 6 (7), 1231-1237CODEN: JPCLCD; ISSN:1948-7185. (American Chemical Society)
        Photoinduced charge transfer (CT) plays a central role in biol. significant systems and in applications that harvest solar energy. The authors study the relation of CT kinetics and conformation in a mol. triad. The triad, consisting of carotenoid, porphyrin, and fullerene is structurally flexible and able to acquire significantly varied conformations under ambient conditions. With an integrated approach of quantum calcns. and mol. dynamics simulations, the authors compute the rate of CT at two distinctive conformations. The linearly extended conformation, in which the donor (carotenoid) and the acceptor (fullerene) are sepd. by nearly 50 Å, enables charge sepn. through a sequential CT process. A representative bent conformation that is entropically dominant, however, attenuates the CT, although the donor and the acceptor are spatially closer. The computed rate of CT at the linear conformation is in good agreement with measured values. The work provides unique fundamental understanding of the photoinduced CT process in the mol. triad.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXksFSktb0%253D&md5=71e57ade98c20f3318d0fd0866f5cdfd
        open URL
      90. 90
        Gmucová, K.; Nádazzdy, V.; Schauer, F.; Kaiser, M.; Majková, E. Electrochemical Spectroscopic Methods for the Fine Band Gap Electronic Structure Mapping in Organic Semiconductors. J. Phys. Chem. C 2015, 119, 15926– 15934,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpcc.5b04378
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        90
        Electrochemical Spectroscopic Methods for the Fine Band Gap Electronic Structure Mapping in Organic Semiconductors
        Gmucova, Katarina; Nadazdy, Vojtech; Schauer, Frantisek; Kaiser, Michal; Majkova, Eva
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2015), 119 (28), 15926-15934CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        Functionality of org. photonic devices is markedly influenced by the electronic band structure of the used materials. An easy and quick detn. of the d. of states function (DOS) in the whole energy range from HOMO to LUMO, including the presence of defect states in the band gap, is a prerequisite to a successful design of photonic devices. The authors present the fine band gap electronic structure mapping in P3HT with two electrochem. spectroscopic methods: the energy-resolved electrochem. impedance spectroscopy (ER-EIS) and the kinetic sensitive voltcoulometry (VCM). The P3HT exposition to air results in the change of light-induced polaron states in the band gap. The electrochem. measured data are compared with those from the literature, obtained with combined optical spectroscopic methods, elec. methods, or 1st-principles calcns. The ER-EIS method was shown as capable of providing valuable information on the DOS in the whole energy range from HOMO to LUMO, and the VCM method opens the possibility to study sep. the charge transfer (redox) processes with different kinetics.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtVarsrjK&md5=c5e54094e46ac68336e0257ac563c02f
        open URL

        Kroon, R.; Lenes, M.; Hummelen, J. C.; Blom, P. W.; De Boer, B. Small bandgap Polymers for Organic Solar Cells (Polymer Material Development in the Last 5 Years). Polym. Rev. 2008, 48, 531– 582,  DOI: 10.1080/15583720802231833
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        91
        Small Bandgap Polymers for Organic Solar Cells (Polymer Material Development in the Last 5 Years)
        Kroon, Renee; Lenes, Martijn; Hummelen, Jan C.; Blom, Paul W. M.; de Boer, Bert
        Polymer Reviews (Philadelphia, PA, United States) (2008), 48 (3), 531-582CODEN: PRPPCY; ISSN:1558-3724. (Taylor & Francis, Inc.)
        A review on recent developments of small band gap (<2.0 eV) polymer materials for photovoltaic applications. First, an introduction is given regarding the processes governing the exciton dissocn., charge transport requirements, energy level engineering of both donor and acceptor materials, and other parameters detg. the photovoltaic performance. The focus is on polymeric donor materials, which are subdivided by the type of monomeric units that constitute the backbone. The synthetic methods and conditions, processing of the devices, and the device performances are summarized. To enhance efficiencies further, research activities for new materials are needed with better aligned energy levels. One interesting approach is by narrowing the donor bandgap to enhance light absorption.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

      93. 93
        Lopez, S. A.; Sanchez-Lengeling, B.; de Goes Soares, J.; Aspuru-Guzik, A. Design principles and top non-fullerene acceptor candidates for organic photovoltaics. Joule 2017, 1, 857– 870,  DOI: 10.1016/j.joule.2017.10.006
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        93
        Design Principles and Top Non-Fullerene Acceptor Candidates for Organic Photovoltaics
        Lopez, Steven A.; Sanchez-Lengeling, Benjamin; Soares, Julio de Goes; Aspuru-Guzik, Alan
        Joule (2017), 1 (4), 857-870CODEN: JOULBR; ISSN:2542-4351. (Cell Press)
        Non-fullerene acceptors in org. photovoltaics (OPVs) continue to improve upon the shortcomings of many fullerene-based solar cells. We explored the chem. space of over 51,000 non-fullerene acceptors featuring 106 common moieties from the org. electronics literature, including naphthalene diimides, benzathiadiazoles, and fused fluoroanthenediimides. We identify top candidates featuring optimal energy level offsets, based on a well-studied electron-donor: poly[N-9'-heptadecanyl-2,7-carbazole-alt-5,5-(4',7'-di-2-thienyl-2',1',3'-benzothiadiazole)]. The Harvard Clean Energy Project infrastructure was employed through the IBM World Community Grid to carry out quantum mech. calcns. using d. functional theory. Gaussian processes regression was utilized to correct the computed frontier MO energies. Addnl. time-dependent d. functional theory calcns. on a subset of the top candidates refined the narrow band-gap chromophores for OPVs. These results on electron-acceptor materials complement the electronic structure calcns. of over one million electron-donor materials publicly available through our website.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXpvFGhu7o%253D&md5=86b5c57cc28040130f7e03673d4122f1

        This article references 94 other publications.

        1. 1
          Cheng, P.; Li, G.; Zhan, X.; Yang, Y. Next-Generation Organic Photovoltaics Based on Non-Fullerene Acceptors. Nat. Photonics 2018, 12, 131– 142,  DOI: 10.1038/s41566-018-0104-9
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          1
          Next-generation organic photovoltaics based on non-fullerene acceptors
          Cheng, Pei; Li, Gang; Zhan, Xiaowei; Yang, Yang
          Nature Photonics (2018), 12 (3), 131-142CODEN: NPAHBY; ISSN:1749-4885. (Nature Research)
          Over the past three years, a particularly exciting and active area of research within the field of org. photovoltaics has been the use of non-fullerene acceptors (NFAs). Compared with fullerene acceptors, NFAs possess significant advantages including tunability of bandgaps, energy levels, planarity and crystallinity. To date, NFA solar cells have not only achieved impressive power conversion efficiencies of ∼13-14%, but have also shown excellent stability compared with traditional fullerene acceptor solar cells. This Review highlights recent progress on single-junction and tandem NFA solar cells and research directions to achieve even higher efficiencies of 15-20% using NFA-based org. photovoltaics are also proposed.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXjsFWmu7s%253D&md5=4456f7b4531374551561ca2ed0c18972
          open URL
        2. 2
          Sun, C.; Pan, F.; Bin, H.; Zhang, J.; Xue, L.; Qiu, B.; Wei, Z.; Zhang, Z.-G.; Li, Y. A Low Cost and High Performance Polymer Donor Material for Polymer Solar Cells. Nat. Commun. 2018, 9, 743  DOI: 10.1038/s41467-018-03207-x
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          2
          A low cost and high performance polymer donor material for polymer solar cells
          Sun Chenkai; Pan Fei; Bin Haijun; Xue Lingwei; Qiu Beibei; Zhang Zhi-Guo; Li Yongfang; Sun Chenkai; Pan Fei; Bin Haijun; Li Yongfang; Zhang Jianqi; Wei Zhixiang; Li Yongfang
          Nature communications (2018), 9 (1), 743 ISSN:.
          The application of polymer solar cells requires the realization of high efficiency, high stability, and low cost devices. Here we demonstrate a low-cost polymer donor poly[(thiophene)-alt-(6,7-difluoro-2-(2-hexyldecyloxy)quinoxaline)] (PTQ10), which is synthesized with high overall yield of 87.4% via only two-step reactions from cheap raw materials. More importantly, an impressive efficiency of 12.70% is obtained for the devices with PTQ10 as donor, and the efficiency of the inverted structured PTQ10-based device also reaches 12.13% (certificated to be 12.0%). Furthermore, the as-cast devices also demonstrate a high efficiency of 10.41% and the devices exhibit insensitivity of active layer thickness from 100 nm to 300 nm, which is conductive to the large area fabrication of the devices. In considering the advantages of low cost and high efficiency with thickness insensitivity, we believe that PTQ10 will be a promising polymer donor for commercial application of polymer solar cells.
          >> More from SciFinder ®

          Novel D-A-D type dyes based on BODIPY platform for solution processed organic solar cells
          Liao, Junxu; Zhao, Hongbin; Xu, Yongjun; Cai, Zhuodi; Peng, Zaixi; Zhang, Wentao; Zhou, Weinan; Li, Bohong; Zong, Qiao; Yang, Xiaoxi
          Dyes and Pigments (2016), 128 (), 131-140CODEN: DYPIDX; ISSN:0143-7208. (Elsevier Ltd.)
          Four novel sym. donor-acceptor-donor (D-A-D) type B dipyrromethene (BODIPY) based dyes, BDP1-4, featuring an electron-withdrawing BODIPY motif as the central core, and several types of electron-donating segments, including thiophene, bithiophene, fluorene and carbazole, flanked at its 2,6-positions as terminal groups were synthesized and characterized. All of these BDPs exhibit panchromatic absorption covering the wavelength range 300-900 nm with high extinction coeffs. (0.78 × 105 to 1.22 × 105 cm-1 M-1) and relatively lower HOMO energy levels from -5.17 to -5.48 eV. Also, BDP1-4 show good thermal stabilities, excellent film-forming abilities and low fluorescent quantum yields. BDP2 flanking with bithiophene units demonstrates superior charge transport property and favorable nanoscale morphol. relative to BDP1, BDP3 and BDP4. The power conversion efficiency (PCE) values of the org. solar cells (OSCs) based on the BDPs/PC61BM (1:0.5, wt./wt.) are 1.49% for BDP1, 2.15% for BDP2, 1.06% for BDP3 and 1.56% for BDP4, resp.

          Novel BODIPY-C60 derivatives with tuned photophysical and electron-acceptor properties: Isoxazolino[60]fullerene and pyrrolidino[60]fullerene
          Cabrera-Espinoza, Andrea; Insuasty, Braulio; Ortiz, Alejandro
          Journal of Luminescence (2018), 194 (), 729-738CODEN: JLUMA8; ISSN:0022-2313. (Elsevier B.V.)
          Two new BODIPY-C60 systems capable of exhibiting photoinduced charge sepn. have been designed, synthesized and characterized using various techniques. In these derivs., the electron donor was BODIPY with two alkoxyphenylethynyl substituents and a fulleropyrrolidine (B2-Pyr) and isoxazoline linked (B2-Is) at the meso-position of the BODIPY ring served as an electron acceptor. As a result of extended conjugation, the BODIPY-C60 derivs. revealed absorbance and emission covering a wide spectral range. Based on their redox, computational, absorbance and emission data, are suggested that the new B2-Is deriv. showed a better electron affinity that B2-Pyr.

          7
          Optical and Electronic Properties of Molecular Systems Derived from Rhodanine
          Madrid-Usuga, Duvalier; Melo-Luna, Carlos A.; Insuasty, Alberto; Ortiz, Alejandro; Reina, John H.
          Journal of Physical Chemistry A (2018), 122 (43), 8469-8476CODEN: JPCAFH; ISSN:1089-5639. (American Chemical Society)
          Push-pull functional compds. consisting of dicyanorhodanine derivs. have attracted a lot of interest because their optical, electronic, and charge transport properties make them useful as building blocks for org. photovoltaic implementations. The anal. of the frontier MOs shows that the vertical transitions of electronic absorption are characterized as intramol. charge transfer; furthermore, we show that the analyzed compds. exhibit bathochromic displacements when comparing the presence (or absence) of solvent as an interacting medium. In comparison with materials defined by their energy of reorganization of electrons (holes) as electron (hole) transporters, we find a transport hierarchy whereby the mol. (Z)-2-(1,1-dicyanomethylene)-5-[(4-dimethylamino)benzylidene]-1,3-thiazol-4 is better at transporting holes than mol. (Z)-2-(1,1-dicyanomethylene)-5-(tetrathiafulvalene-2-ylidene)-1,3-thiazol-4.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhvV2js7bM&md5=e2f7c5444f0e4b561175d82900084a65
          open URL
        8. 8
          Madrid-Úsuga, D.; Susa, C. E.; Reina, J. H. Room temperature quantum coherence vs. electron transfer in a rhodanine derivative chromophore. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2019, 21, 12640– 12648,  DOI: 10.1039/C9CP01398A
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          8
          Room temperature quantum coherence vs. electron transfer in a rhodanine derivative chromophore
          Madrid-Usuga, Duvalier; Susa, Cristian E.; Reina, John H.
          Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2019), 21 (23), 12640-12648CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          Understanding electron transfer in org. mols. is of great interest in quantum materials for light harvesting, energy conversion and integration of mols. into solar cells. This, however, poses the challenge of designing specific optimal mol. structure for which the processes of ultrafast quantum coherence and electron transport are not so well understood. In this work, we investigate subpicosecond time scale quantum dynamics and electron transfer in an efficient electron acceptor rhodanine chromophoric complex. We consider an open quantum system approach to model the complex-solvent interaction, and compute the crossover from weak to strong dissipation on the reduced system dynamics for both a polar (methanol) and a non polar solvent (toluene). We show that the electron transfer rates are enhanced in the strong chromophore-solvent coupling regime, being the highest transfer rates those found at room temp. Even though the computed dynamics are highly non-Markovian, and they may exhibit a quantum character up to hundreds of femtoseconds, we show that quantum coherence does not necessarily optimize the electron transfer in the chromophore.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtVKnt7bK&md5=ffdb2f9f89af5bc7108c62d5b97b47c6
          open URL

          Ganesamoorthy, R.; Sathiyan, G.; Sakthivel, P. Fullerene based acceptors for efficient bulk heterojunction organic solar cell applications. Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells 2017, 161, 102– 148,  DOI: 10.1016/j.solmat.2016.11.024
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          9
          Review: Fullerene based acceptors for efficient bulk heterojunction organic solar cell applications
          Ganesamoorthy, Ramasamy; Sathiyan, Govindasamy; Sakthivel, Pachagounder
          Solar Energy Materials & Solar Cells (2017), 161 (), 102-148CODEN: SEMCEQ; ISSN:0927-0248. (Elsevier B.V.)
          Bulk hetro-junction org. solar cells (BHJ-OSCs) which made by coating the blend of highly electron rich, poly-3-hexylthiophene (P3HT) as a donor and extremely electron deficient, sol. C60 deriv., [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid Me ester (PC61BM) as an acceptor between the high work function pos. electrode, ITO and low work function metal neg. electrode Al, showed exciting results than the bilayer counterpart in the last two decades, thus the scientific circle and solar cell manufg. groups are focusing on this treasured field. Fullerene deriv. based BHJ-OSCs showed astonishing efficiencies due the high donor-acceptor (D-A) interface, high open-circuit voltage (Voc), easy processing, and thermal stability. Hence, the design of the fullerene deriv. plays a vital role in the efficiency of the OSCs. Numerous papers were published on the PC61/71BM and various functionally modified fullerene acceptors in the past several years with higher efficiency, higher LUMO level, and improved soly. The sym. structure of PC61BM showed high aggregation properties, insufficient absorption in the visible region, but unsym. PC71BM had a good optical absorption in the visible region, hence it was the most desirable choice for best performing solar cells. From the comparison, it was clear that the modification in the PC61/71BM core with aryl group, alkyl chain length, and end group modification didn't show any significant difference in the PCE with the P3HT polymer donor in BHJ-OSCs device structure. Fullerenes multi-adducts performed better than the PC61/71BM due to the development in the Voc. In multi-functionalization, mainly bis-functionalization showed better performance than mono-adduct. C60 and C70 based hetro bis-adducts namely, C60(CH2)(Ind), and OQMF70 showed the highest PCE of 5.90%, and 6.61% resp., which was comparable with the indene based bis-adducts. Commonly, tris-adduct fullerenes showed the lowest PCE due to the isomer effect and electron trapping, but OQBMF was a hetro tris-adduct of C60-methanofullerenes, which showed a excellent PCE of 6.43% due to improved Voc. Similarly, indene substituted C60 and C70 fullerenes based bis-adducts showed supreme PCE, of 6.5% (IC60BA) and ∼6.7% (IC70BA) resp., peak PCE was attributed to the high electron donating indene group, which enhanced the LUMO level due to the shrinkage in the π-system. The dihydronaphthyl based fullerene bis-adduct derivs. such as, NC60BA, and NC70BA showed the best performance of 5.37%, and 5.95% resp., than the mono-adduct. Even though abundant fulleropyrrolidines were reported, the performance of the fulleropyrrolidines based device was very deprived than the PC61/71BM based devices. Though the OSCs are comparatively efficient for com. application due the insufficient efficiency and lower environmental stability factors controls the early arrival to the market. Therefore, it is essential to go through the recent fullerene derivs. based literatures, including mono-, bis-, tris- and multi-adducts of various methanofullerene deriv., indene based fullerene derivs., dihydronaptyl substituted fullerenes, fulleropyrolidines, 1,2 and 1,4-adducts and fullerene derivs. for OSCs applications. In this regard, we discussed the present development in fullerene deriv. and summarized the efficient fullerene derivs. for the BHJ-OSCs application and suggest a possible scenario for the future development in the fullerene cage.
          >> More from SciFinder ®

          Review of carbazole based conjugated molecules for highly efficient organic solar cell application
          Sathiyan, Govindasamy; Sivakumar, E. K. T.; Ganesamoorthy, Ramasamy; Thangamuthu, Rangasamy; Sakthivel, Pachagoundar
          Tetrahedron Letters (2016), 57 (3), 243-252CODEN: TELEAY; ISSN:0040-4039. (Elsevier Ltd.)
          A review. Carbazole based mols. are more important in org. solar cell (OSC) applications, because carbazole derivs. have more thermal stability, high hole transporting property, more electron rich (p-type) material, higher photocond., and better chem. stability. This review deals with bulk heterojunction org. solar cell (BHJ OSC) devices, structures, working principle, device characterization, perovskite type solar cell, and studies of the photovoltaic performance of carbazole based derivs. such as 2,7-carbazole, indolo[3,2-b]carbazole contg. donors (D) coupled with various acceptors (A) benzothiadiazole, thiazolothiazole, diketopyrrolopyrrole, and quinoxaline that are reported during the last decade and also dye-sensitized solar cell (DSSC) performance of carbazole derivs. The authors will briefly outline the relation between the structure and power conversion efficiencies (PCEs).

          Ware, W.; Wright, T.; Mao, Y.; Han, S.; Guffie, J.; Danilov, E. O.; Rech, J.; You, W.; Luo, Z.; Gautam, B. Aggregation Controlled Charge Generation in Fullerene Based Bulk Heterojunction Polymer Solar Cells: Effect of Additive. Polymers 2021, 13, 115,  DOI: 10.3390/polym13010115

          11
          Aggregation controlled charge generation in fullerene based bulk heterojunction polymer solar cells: effect of additive
          Ware, Washat; Wright, Tia; Mao, Yimin; Han, Shubo; Guffie, Jessa; Danilov, Evgeny O.; Rech, Jeromy; You, Wei; Luo, Zhiping; Gautam, Bhoj
          Polymers (Basel, Switzerland) (2021), 13 (1), 115CODEN: POLYCK; ISSN:2073-4360. (MDPI AG)
          Optimization of charge generation in polymer blends is crucial for the fabrication of highly efficient polymer solar cells. While the impacts of the polymer chem. structure, energy alignment, and interface on charge generation have been well studied, not much is known about the impact of polymer aggregation on charge generation. Here, we studied the impact of aggregation on charge generation using transient absorption spectroscopy, neutron scattering, and at. force microscopy. Our measurements indicate that the 1,8-diiodooctane additive can change the aggregation behavior of poly(benzodithiophene-alt-dithienyl difluorobenzotriazole) (PBnDT-FTAZ) and phenyl-C61-butyric acid Me ester (PCBM)polymer blends and impact the charge generation process. Our observations show that the charge generation can be optimized by tuning the aggregation in polymer blends, which can be beneficial for the design of highly efficient fullerene-based org. photovoltaic devices.

          El-Khouly, M. E.; Fukuzumi, S.; D’Souza, F. Photosynthetic Antenna–Reaction Center Mimicry by Using Boron Dipyrromethene Sensitizers. Chem. Phys. Chem. 2014, 15, 30– 47,  DOI: 10.1002/cphc.201300715
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          12
          Photosynthetic antenna-reaction center mimicry by using boron dipyrromethene sensitizers
          El-Khouly Mohamed E; Fukuzumi Shunichi; D'Souza Francis
          Chemphyschem : a European journal of chemical physics and physical chemistry (2014), 15 (1), 30-47 ISSN:.
          Various molecular and supramolecular systems have been synthesized and characterized recently to mimic the functions of photosynthesis, in which solar energy conversion is achieved. Artificial photosynthesis consists of light-harvesting and charge-separation processes together with catalytic units of water oxidation and reduction. Among the organic molecules, derivatives of BF2-chelated dipyrromethene (BODIPY), "porphyrin's little sister", have been widely used in constructing these artificial photosynthetic models due to their unique properties. In these photosynthetic models, BODIPYs act as not only excellent antenna molecules, but also as electron-donor and -acceptor molecules in both the covalently linked molecular and supramolecular systems formed by axial coordination, hydrogen bonding, or crown ether complexation. The relationships between the structures and photochemical reactivities of these novel molecular and supramolecular systems are discussed in relation to the efficiency of charge separation and charge recombination. Femto- and nanosecond transient absorption and photoelectrochemical techniques have been employed in these studies to give clear evidence for the occurrence of energy- and electron-transfer reactions and to determine their rates and efficiencies.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC2c7nvFensw%253D%253D&md5=de1850c67dec1899a61fe14b3dc030f9
          open URL

          Guo, S.; Ma, L.; Zhao, J.; Küçüköz, B.; Karatay, A.; Hayvali, M.; Yaglioglu, H. G.; Elmali, A. BODIPY Triads Triplet Photosensitizers Enhanced with Intramolecular Resonance Energy Transfer (RET): Broadband Visible Light Absorption and Application in Photooxidation. Chem.           13
          BODIPY triads triplet photosensitizers enhanced with intramolecular resonance energy transfer (RET): broadband visible light absorption and application in photooxidation
          Guo, Song; Ma, Lihua; Zhao, Jianzhang; Kuecuekoez, Betuel; Karatay, Ahmet; Hayvali, Mustafa; Yaglioglu, H. Gul; Elmali, Ayhan
          Chemical Science (2014), 5 (2), 489-500CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          Resonance energy transfer (RET) was used to enhance the light absorption in triad triplet photosensitizers to access strong and broadband absorption in visible region (from 450-750 nm). This strategy was demonstrated by prepn. of (BODIPY)2-diiodo-aza-BODIPY triad (B-2) and (carbazole-styryl BODIPY)2-diiodo-aza-BODIPY triad (B-3), in which the energy donor (BODIPY or styryl-BODIPY) and the energy acceptor (aza-BODIPY, also as the spin converter) parts were connected by click chem. Both the energy donors and the energy acceptors show strong absorption in the visible spectral region, but at different wavelengths, therefore the triads show broadband absorption in visible spectra region, e.g. the two major absorption bands of B-3 are located at 593 nm and 683 nm, with .vepsiln. up to 220 000 M-1 cm-1 and 81 000 M-1 cm-1, resp. For comparison, a ref. compd. with only diiodo-aza-BODIPY as the light-harvesting unit was prepd. (B-1), which shows only one major absorption band in visible spectral region. Fluorescence studies indicated intramol. energy transfer for these BODIPY hybrids, a conclusion which is supported by the femtosecond time-resolved transient absorption spectroscopy. Nanosecond transient absorption spectra show that triplet excited states of the dyad and the triad are localized on the iodo-aza-BODIPY part. The compds. were used as triplet photosensitizers for singlet oxygen (1O2) mediated photooxidn. of 1,5-dihydroxylnaphthalene and the photosensitizing ability of the new triplet photosensitizers are more efficient than the mono-chromophore based triplet photosensitizers. The mol. design rationale of these RET-enhanced multi-chromophore triplet photosensitizer is useful for development of efficient triplet photosensitizers and for their applications in photocatalysis, photodynamic therapy, photovoltaics and upconversion.

          BODIPY Dye, the Most Versatile Fluorophore Ever?
          Banuelos, Jorge
          Chemical Record (2016), 16 (1), 335-348CODEN: CRHEAK; ISSN:1528-0691. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          BODIPY laser dyes constitute a fascinating topic of research in modern photochem. due to the large variety of options its chromophore offers, which is ready available for a multitude of synthetic routes. Indeed, in the literature one can find a huge battery of compds. based on the indacene core. The possibility of modulating the spectroscopic properties or inducing new photophys. processes by the substitution pattern of the BODIPY dyes has boosted the no. of scientific and technol. applications for these fluorophores. Along the following lines, I will overview the main results achieved in our lab. with BODIPYs oriented to optoelectronic as well to biophotonic applications, stressing the more relevant photophys. issues to be considered in the design of a tailor-made BODIPY for a certain application and pointing out some of the remaining challenges.

          Bandi, V.; Gobeze, H. B.; D’Souza, F. Ultrafast Photoinduced Electron Transfer and Charge Stabilization in Donor–Acceptor Dyads Capable of Harvesting Near-Infrared Light. Chem. – Eur. J. 2015, 21, 11483– 11494,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201500728
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          15
          Ultrafast photoinduced electron transfer and charge stabilization in donor-acceptor dyads capable of harvesting near-infrared light
          Bandi, Venugopal; Gobeze, Habtom B.; D'Souza, Francis
          Chemistry - A European Journal (2015), 21 (32), 11483-11494CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          To harvest energy from the near-IR (near-IR) and IR (IR) regions of the electromagnetic spectrum, which constitutes nearly 70% of the solar radiation, there is a great demand for near-IR and IR light-absorbing sensitizers that are capable of undergoing ultrafast photoinduced electron transfer when connected to a suitable electron acceptor. Towards achieving this goal, in the present study, we report multistep syntheses of dyads derived from structurally modified BF2-chelated azadipyrromethene (ADP; to extend absorption and emission into the near-IR region) and fullerene as electron-donor and electron-acceptor entities, resp. The newly synthesized dyads were fully characterized based on optical absorbance, fluorescence, geometry optimization, and electrochem. studies. The established energy level diagram revealed the possibility of electron transfer either from the singlet excited near-IR sensitizer or singlet excited fullerene. Femtosecond and nanosecond transient absorption studies were performed to gather evidence of excited state electron transfer and to evaluate the kinetics of charge sepn. and charge recombination processes. These studies revealed the occurrence of ultrafast photoinduced electron transfer leading to charge stabilization in the dyads, and populating the triplet states of ADP, benzanulated-ADP and benzanulated thiophene-ADP in the resp. dyads, and triplet state of C60 in the case of BF2-chelated dipyrromethene derived dyad during charge recombination. The present findings reveal that these sensitizers are suitable for harvesting light energy from the near-IR region of the solar spectrum and for building fast-responding optoelectronic devices operating under near-IR radiation input.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtFWgtb7N&md5=33d56a413a5f702040e26bed5f244a5a
          open URL

          Liu, J.-Y.; Hou, X.-N.; Tian, Y.; Jiang, L.; Deng, S.; Röder, B.; Ermilov, E. A. Photoinduced Energy and Charge Transfer in a Bis (triphenylamine)–BODIPY–C60 Artificial Photosynthetic System. RSC Adv. 2016, 6, 57293– 57305,  DOI: 10.1039/C6RA06841C
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          16
          Photoinduced energy and charge transfer in a bis(triphenylamine)-BODIPY-C60 artificial photosynthetic system
          Liu, Jian-Yong; Hou, Xue-Ni; Tian, Ye; Jiang, Lizhi; Deng, Shuiquan; Roder, Beate; Ermilov, Eugeny A.
          RSC Advances (2016), 6 (62), 57293-57305CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          Triphenylamines (TPAs), boron dipyrromethenes (BODIPYs) and fullerenes C60 are excellent building blocks for the design of artificial photosynthetic systems. In the present work, we report the synthesis, characterization and detailed photophys. studies of a novel (TPA)2-BODIPY-C60 tetrad in polar and nonpolar solvents. The absorption spectrum of this compd. covered virtually the entire visible region (350-700 nm) and could be interpreted as a superposition of the spectra of individual components. Upon TPA-part excitation, a fast and very efficient excitation energy transfer (EET) delivers the excitation to the BODIPY moiety resulting in complete quenching of the TPA first excited singlet state as well as the appearance of the BODIPY fluorescence. The efficiency of EET process was estd. to be 1. Direct or indirect (via EET) excitation of the BODIPY-part of the tetrad is followed by photoinduced charge transfer to the charge-sepd. state BODIPẎ +-C60̇ - irresp. of the solvent used. In polar N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) charge recombination occurs directly to the ground state with the charge recombination rate, kCR, slower than 108 s-1, whereas in nonpolar toluene (TOL) a small energy gap between the charge-sepd. state and first excited singlet state of the BODIPY moiety facilitates the back charge transfer process. The latter results in the appearance of thermally activated delayed fluorescence. The rate of charge sepn. was found to be ca. 2 times faster in TOL than in DMF.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XpsVGls7o%253D&md5=439473bbae8bfba080d3e9e4f8f7d479
          open URL

          Gao, D.; Aly, S. M.; Karsenti, P.-L.; Brisard, G.; Harvey, P. D. Ultrafast Energy and Electron Transfers in Structurally Well Addressable BODIPY-Porphyrin-Fullerene Polyads. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2017, 19, 2926– 2939,  DOI: 10.1039/C6CP08000F
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          17
          Ultrafast energy and electron transfers in structurally well addressable BODIPY-porphyrin-fullerene polyads
          Gao, Di; Aly, Shawkat M.; Karsenti, Paul-Ludovic; Brisard, Gessie; Harvey, Pierre D.
          Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2017), 19 (4), 2926-2939CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          Two electron transfer polyads built upon [C60]-[ZnP]-[BODIPY] (1) and [ZnP]-[ZnP](-[BODIPY])(-[C60]) (2), where [C60] = N-methyl-2-phenyl-3,4-fulleropyrrolidine, [BODIPY] = boron dipyrromethane, and [ZnP] = zinc(II) porphyrin, were synthesized along with their corresponding energy transfer polyads [ZnP]-[BODIPY] (1a) and [ZnP]-[ZnP]-[BODIPY] (2a) as well as relevant models. These polyads were studied using cyclic voltammetry, DFT computations, steady state and time-resolved fluorescence spectroscopy, and fs transient absorption spectroscopy. The rates for energy transfer, kET, [BODIPY]* → [ZnP] are ∼2.8 × 1010 s-1 for both 1a and 2a, with an efficiency of 99%. Concurrently, the fast appearance of the [C60]-· anion for 1 and 2 indicates that the charge sepn. occurs on the 20-30 ps timescale with the rates of electron transfer, ket, [ZnP]*/[C60] → [ZnP]+· /[C60]-· of ∼0.9 × 1010 to ∼3.8 × 1010 s-1. The latter value is among the fastest for these types of polyads. Conversely, the charge recombination operates on the ns timescale. These rates are comparable to or faster than those reported for other more flexible [C60]-[ZnP]-[BODIPY] polyads, which can be rationalized by the donor-acceptor sepns.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XitFCmu73L&md5=447b52e8c8d97c1360d8e859666afd92
          open URL
        18. 18
          Amin, A. N.; El-Khouly, M. E.; Subbaiyan, N. K.; Zandler, M. E.; Fukuzumi, S.; D’Souza, F. A novel BF 2-chelated azadipyrromethene–fullerene dyad: synthesis, electrochemistry and photodynamics. Chem. Commun. 2012, 48, 206– 208,  DOI: 10.1039/C1CC16071K
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          18
          A novel BF2-chelated azadipyrromethene-fullerene dyad: synthesis, electrochemistry and photodynamics
          Amin, Anu N.; El-Khouly, Mohamed E.; Subbaiyan, Navaneetha K.; Zandler, Melvin E.; Fukuzumi, Shunichi; D'Souza, Francis
          Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2012), 48 (2), 206-208CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          The synthesis, structure, electrochem. and photodynamics of a BF2-chelated azadipyrromethene-fullerene dyad are reported in comparison with BF2-chelated azadipyrromethene without fullerene. The attachment of fullerene resulted in efficient generation of the triplet excited state of the azadipyrromethene via photoinduced electron transfer.

          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhsFGqu77O&md5=3f2dad8d2ef1977e7d6f0aa9ebea0748

        19. 19
          Shi, W.-J.; El-Khouly, M. E.; Ohkubo, K.; Fukuzumi, S.; Ng, D. K. Photosynthetic Antenna-Reaction Center Mimicry with a Covalently Linked Monostyryl Boron-Dipyrromethene–Aza-Boron-Dipyrromethene–C60 Triad. Chem. – Eur. J. 2013, 19, 11332– 11341,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201300318
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          19
          Photosynthetic Antenna-Reaction Center Mimicry with a Covalently Linked Monostyryl Boron-Dipyrromethene-Aza-Boron-Dipyrromethene-C60 Triad
          Shi, Wen-Jing; El-Khouly, Mohamed E.; Ohkubo, Kei; Fukuzumi, Shunichi; Ng, Dennis K. P.
          Chemistry - A European Journal (2013), 19 (34), 11332-11341CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          An efficient functional mimic of the photosynthetic antenna-reaction center has been designed and synthesized. The simulation, physicochem. contains a near-IR-absorbing aza-boron-dipyrromethene (ADP) that is connected to a monostyryl boron-dipyrromethene (BDP) by a click reaction and to a fullerene (C60) using the Prato reaction. The intramol. photoinduced energy and electron-transfer processes of this triad as well as the corresponding dyads BDP-ADP and ADP-C60 have been studied with steady-state and time-resolved absorption and fluorescence spectroscopic methods in benzonitrile. Upon excitation, the BDP moiety of the triad is significantly quenched due to energy transfer to the ADP core, which subsequently transfers an electron to the fullerene unit. Cyclic and differential pulse voltammetric studies have revealed the redox states of the components, which allow estn. of the energies of the charge-sepd. states. Such calcns. show that electron transfer from the singlet excited ADP (1ADP*) to C60 yielding ADP.+-C60.- is energetically favorable. By using femtosecond laser radiation flash photolysis, concrete evidence has been obtained for the occurrence of energy transfer from 1BDP* to ADP in the dyad BDP-ADP and electron transfer from 1ADP* to C60 in the dyad ADP-C60. Sequential energy and electron transfer have also been clearly obsd. in the triad BDP-ADP-C60. By monitoring the rise of ADP emission, it has been found that the rate of energy transfer is fast (≈1011 s-1). The dynamics of electron transfer through 1ADP* has also been studied by monitoring the formation of C60 radical anion at 1000 nm. A fast charge-sepn. process from 1ADP* to C60 has been detected, which gives the relatively long-lived BDP-ADP.+C60.- with a lifetime of 1.47 ns. As shown by nanosecond transient absorption measurements, the charge-sepd. state decays slowly to populate mainly the triplet state of ADP before returning to the ground state. These findings show that the dyads BDP-ADP and ADP-C60, and the triad BDP-ADP-C60 are interesting artificial analogs that can mimic the antenna and reaction center of the natural photosynthetic systems.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtFShsLbJ&md5=763c155b424c4687e01ef0c0e7983b94
          open URL
        20. 20
          Yee, M.-c.; Fas, S. C.; Stohlmeyer, M. M.; Wandless, T. J.; Cimprich, K. A. A cell-Permeable, Activity-Based Probe for Protein and Lipid Kinases. J. Biol. Chem. 2005, 280, 29053– 29059,  DOI: 10.1074/jbc.M504730200
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          20
          A Cell-permeable, Activity-based Probe for Protein and Lipid Kinases
          Yee, Muh-ching; Fas, Stefanie C.; Stohlmeyer, Michelle M.; Wandless, Thomas J.; Cimprich, Karlene A.
          Journal of Biological Chemistry (2005), 280 (32), 29053-29059CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
          Protein and lipid kinases are two important classes of biomedically relevant enzymes. The expression and activity of many kinases are known to be dysregulated in a variety of diseases, and proteomic tools that can assess the presence and activity of these enzymes are likely to be useful for their evaluation. Because many of the mechanisms by which protein kinases can become unregulated involve post-translational modifications or changes in protein localization, they can only be detected by examg. protein activity, sometimes within the context of the living cell. Wortmannin is a steroid-derived fungal metabolite that covalently inhibits both protein and lipid kinases. Here the authors describe the synthesis of three wortmannin derivs., biotin-wortmannin, BODIPY-wortmannin, and tetramethylrhodamine-wortmannin. The authors demonstrate that these reagents exhibit reactivity similarly as wortmannin and react with members of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase and PI3-kinase related kinase families in cellular lysates. Moreover, in some cases these reagents can differentiate between the active and inactive forms of the enzyme, indicating that they are activity-based probes. The reagents also exhibit complementary properties. The biotin-wortmannin reagent is effective in the isolation of labeled proteins; all three can be used for protein labeling, and BODIPY-wortmannin is cell-permeable and can be used to label proteins within cells.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXntVegs70%253D&md5=ea78c6386b56181265e49ec619ee7e9e
          open URL

          Tan, K.; Jaquinod, L.; Paolesse, R.; Nardis, S.; Di Natale, C.; Di Carlo, A.; Prodi, L.; Montalti, M.; Zaccheroni, N.; Smith, K. M. Synthesis and Characterization of β-Fused Porphyrin-BODIPY Dyads. Tetrahedron 2004, 60, 1099– 1106,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tet.2003.11.072
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          21
          Synthesis and characterization of β-fused porphyrin-BODIPY dyads
          Tan, Kenyu; Jaquinod, Laurent; Paolesse, Roberto; Nardis, Sara; Di Natale, Corrado; Di Carlo, Aldo; Prodi, Luca; Montalti, Marco; Zaccheroni, Nelsi; Smith, Kevin M.
          Tetrahedron (2004), 60 (5), 1099-1106CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
          Novel dyads in which a porphyrin ring is directly fused through two β-pyrrolic carbons to a BODIPY moiety were prepd. using a stepwise approach starting from the Cu(II) complex of pyrrolo[2,3-c]-5,10,15,20-tetraphenylporphyrin. Formylation and reaction with 3,5-dimethylpyrrole afforded Cu(HL) (H3L = I); subsequent BF2 complexation gave the TPP-BODIPY dyad CuL(BF2) in reasonable yields. Demetalation in TFA/H2SO4 led to the corresponding free base BF2(H2L), opening the way to the subsequent prepn. of ZnL(BF2). Both BF2(H2L) and ZnL(BF2) exhibited complex optical spectra with an intensely red-shifted Q-band. Luminescence spectra displayed a very intense band around 700 nm making these species suitable as near-IR dyes and sensors in biol. media. Optical analyses of BF2(H2L), using the INDO/SCI technique, were performed to obtain information to establish the origin of the novel optical properties. The optical properties of BF2(H2L) cannot be attributed to deformation of the mol. skeleton, but derive from the increased extension of the conjugation between the TPP and BODIPY π-systems.

        22. 22
          Gautam, P.; Misra, R.; Thomas, M. B.; D’Souza, F. Ultrafast Charge-Separation in Triphenylamine-BODIPY-Derived Triads Carrying Centrally Positioned, Highly Electron-Deficient, Dicyanoquinodimethane or Tetracyanobutadiene Electron-Acceptors. Chem. – Eur. J. 2017, 23, 9192– 9200,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201701604
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          22
          Ultrafast Charge-Separation in Triphenylamine-BODIPY-Derived Triads Carrying Centrally Positioned, Highly Electron-Deficient, Dicyanoquinodimethane or Tetracyanobutadiene Electron-Acceptors
          Gautam, Prabhat; Misra, Rajneesh; Thomas, Michael B.; D'Souza, Francis
          Chemistry - A European Journal (2017), 23 (38), 9192-9200CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          A series of new triphenylamine (TPA)-substituted BODIPYs 1-3 have been designed and synthesized through the Pd-catalyzed Sonogashira cross-coupling and [2+2] cycloaddn.-retroelectrocyclization reactions in good yields. This procedure yielded highly electron-deficient tetracyanobutadiene (TCBD) or dicyanoquinodimethane (DCNQ) electron-acceptor units centrally located at the TPA-BODIPY system. As a consequence, significant perturbation of the photonic and electronic properties was obsd. The triads 2 and 3 showed red-shifted absorption, in addn. to a strong charge-transfer-type absorption in the case of 3. The electrochem. studies revealed multi-redox processes involving the TPA, TCBD or DCNQ and BODIPY entities. The computational studies were performed at the B3LYP/6-31G** level to elucidate the geometry and electronic structures. An energy level diagram established for triads 2 and 3 revealed that the photoinduced charge-sepn. from the 1BODIPY* is thermodynamically possible. In addn., charge transfer from TPA to TCBD in 2 and DCNQ in 3 was also possible. These charge transfer mechanisms were confirmed by photochem. studies performed using time-resolved emission and femtosecond-transient-absorption studies in solvents of varying polarity. Ultrafast charge-sepn. has been witnessed in these closely spaced, strongly interacting triads. The charge-sepd. state returned to the ground state without populating the 3BODIPY*.
          >> More from SciFinder ®

          Achieving the highest efficiency using a BODIPY core decorated with dithiafulvalene wings for small molecule based solution-processed organic solar cells
          Srinivasa Rao, R.; Bagui, Anirban; Hanumantha Rao, G.; Gupta, Vinay; Singh, Surya Prakash

          A novel B dipyrromethene based dye, coded as BODIPY-DTF, decorated with dithiafulvalene wings was developed for solar cell application. A very high efficiency of 7.2% was achieved, which is the highest reported value so far for BODIPY based donors. A remarkable value of ∼88.1% of external quantum efficiency also was obsd. at 371 nm.

        25. 25
          Heeger, A. J. 25th Anniversary Article, Bulk Heterojunction Solar Cells: Understanding the Mechanism of Operation. Adv. Mater. 2014, 26, 10– 28,  DOI: 10.1002/adma.201304373
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          25
          25th Anniversary Article: Bulk Heterojunction Solar Cells: Understanding the Mechanism of Operation
          Heeger, Alan J.
          Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2014), 26 (1), 10-28CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
          A review. The status of understanding of the operation of bulk heterojunction solar cells is discussed. Because the carrier photoexcitation recombination lengths are typically 10 nm in these disordered materials, the length scale for self-assembly must be on the order of 10-20 nm. Expts. have verified the existence of the bulk heterojunction nanostructure, but the morphol. remains complex and a limiting factor. Three steps are required for generation of elec. power: (a) absorption of photons from the sun; (b) photoinduced charge sepn. and the generation of mobile carriers; and (c) collection of electrons and holes at opposite electrodes. The ultrafast charge transfer process arises from fundamental quantum uncertainty; mobile carriers are directly generated (electrons in the acceptor domains and holes in the donor domains) by the ultrafast charge transfer (≈70%) with ≈30% generated by exciton diffusion to a charge sepg. heterojunction. Sweep-out of the mobile carriers by the internal field prior to recombination is essential for high performance. Bimol. recombination dominates in materials where the donor and acceptor phases are pure. Impurities degrade performance by introducing Shockley-Read-Hall decay. The review concludes with a summary of the problems to be solved to achieve the predicted power conversion efficiencies of >20% for a single cell.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhvVykur%252FN&md5=f57101d8c6e984e8760edcd6651e124a
          open URL

          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
