          Mulligan, C. J.; Wilson, M.; Bryant, G.; Vaughan, B.; Zhou, X.; Belcher, W. J.; Dastoor, P. C. A Projection of Commercial-Scale Organic Photovoltaic Module Costs. Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells 2014, 120, 9– 17,  DOI: 10.1016/j.solmat.2013.07.041
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          83
          A projection of commercial-scale organic photovoltaic module costs
          Mulligan, Cara J.; Wilson, Mitchell; Bryant, Glenn; Vaughan, Ben; Zhou, Xiaojing; Belcher, Warwick J.; Dastoor, Paul C.
          Solar Energy Materials & Solar Cells (2014), 120 (PA), 9-17CODEN: SEMCEQ; ISSN:0927-0248. (Elsevier B.V.)
          Org. photovoltaics (OPVs) are a recent technol. that has gained much attention as a potential low cost power source. Despite this promise, there is a lack of published studies that address the likely cost of com.-scale OPV modules. In this work, an engineering study est. has been performed to det. the projected cost of mass-manufd. OPV modules. The materials, prodn. capital and operating costs have been calcd. and sensitivity analyses performed to det. the parameters of greatest economic influence. Significantly, the model includes a calcn. of the costs required to establish bulk manufg. of the current high cost speciality materials components, encompassing synthesis and assocd. chem. plant design. The economic modeling reveals that the calcd. mass-manufd. OPV module costs are considerably lower than current literature ests., with OPV modules costed at $7.85 per square metre with an uncertainty of±30%. Total module cost was found to be most sensitive to the plastic substrate prices, while the prodn. rate did not have a significant impact on module cost for rates above ∼50 m2/min. The results highlight the future cost potential of OPV technol. and can be used to assist with scale-up planning.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhsFaqt7%252FM&md5=58a51116ec8863db81e5d02e5e3949bf
          open URL
        84. 84
          Po, R.; Bernardi, A.; Calabrese, A.; Carbonera, C.; Corso, G.; Pellegrino, A. From Lab to Fab: How Must the Polymer Solar Cell Materials Design Change?–an Industrial Perspective. Energy Environ. Sci. 2014, 7, 925– 943,  DOI: 10.1039/c3ee43460e
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          84
          From lab to fab: how must the polymer solar cell materials design change? - an industrial perspective
          Po, Riccardo; Bernardi, Andrea; Calabrese, Anna; Carbonera, Chiara; Corso, Gianni; Pellegrino, Andrea
          Energy & Environmental Science (2014), 7 (3), 925-943CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          A review. Org. photovoltaic (OPV) devices, in particular polymer solar cells, made by soln. processed org. materials have shown great promise as a disruptive technol. for affordable electricity. Even though recent advances look impressive on paper, until now the commercialization of OPV has been hampered by the difficulty of converting lab produced "champion" cell figures into reliable industrial-scale product performances. A key factor to achieve this condition is to develop OPV materials (polymer donors, acceptors, buffer materials, electrodes materials and encapsulants) exhibiting the required tech. and economic characteristics to be conveniently used in an industrial environment. The well established strategies for the design of materials for efficient lab-scale OPV devices are not sufficient when large-area printed panels are concerned. A no. of addnl. requirements, normally not addressed in the lab. context, must be met: the materials must be easily accessible as pure compds. in few synthetic steps from cheap starting compds., need to be stable and sol. enough to afford ink formulations processable with roll-to-roll compatible equipment; solvent and solvent additives should be easily removable after printing, and possibly should be environmentally friendly compds.; the layers should achieve a stable morphol. under mild conditions (low temps. and short times); the above mentioned materials can be screened on glass substrates, but should be finally tested on plastic films, protected through a scalable encapsulation technique. The more researchers adhere to these guidelines, the greater the possibility for OPV to demonstrate at last its enormous potential on the industrial scale.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXjtlKis78%253D&md5=fe423b60e6ba84da8498c375d0605b8a
          open URL
        85. 85
          Marrocchi, A.; Lanari, D.; Facchetti, A.; Vaccaro, L. Poly(3-Hexylthiophene): Synthetic Methodologies and Properties in Bulk Heterojunction Solar Cells. Energy Environ. Sci. 2012, 5, 8457– 8474,  DOI: 10.1039/c2ee22129b
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          85
          Poly(3-hexylthiophene): synthetic methodologies and properties in bulk heterojunction solar cells
          Marrocchi, Assunta; Lanari, Daniela; Facchetti, Antonio; Vaccaro, Luigi
          Energy & Environmental Science (2012), 5 (9), 8457-8474CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
          A review. Poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT) remains of significant importance as a prototypical benchmark hole conductor material in Org. Photovoltaics (OPVs). In this review we discuss synthetic strategies to P3HT, particularly focusing on those leading to the regioregular form and discussing key phys. and morphol. properties. Finally, a survey and a brief discussion of P3HT performance in bulk-heterojunction (BHJ) OPVs are also provided.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xht1WrsLfI&md5=c8bcf596d9b951e8d3b09d851263087b
          open URL
        86. 86
          Sista, P.; Ghosh, K.; Martinez, J. S.; Rocha, R. C. Polythiophenes in Biological Applications. J. Nanosci. Nanotechnol. 2014, 14, 250– 272,  DOI: 10.1166/jnn.2014.9111
          [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
          86
          Polythiophenes in biological applications
          Sista, Prakash; Ghosh, Koushik; Martinez, Jennifer S.; Rocha, Reginaldo C.
          Journal of Nanoscience and Nanotechnology (2014), 14 (1), 250-272CODEN: JNNOAR; ISSN:1533-4880. (American Scientific Publishers)
          A review. Polythiophene and its derivs. have shown tremendous potential for interfacing elec. conducting polymers with biol. applications. These semiconducting org. polymers are relatively soft, conduct electrons and ions, have low cytotoxicity, and can undergo facile chem. modifications. In addn., the redn. in elec. impedance of electrodes coated with polythiophenes may prove to be invaluable for a stable and permanent connection between devices and biol. tissues. This review article focuses on the synthesis and some key applications of polythiophenes in multidisciplinary areas at the interface with biol. These polymers have shown tremendous potential in biol. applications such as diagnostics, therapy, drug delivery, imaging, implant devices and artificial organs.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXks1Sjs78%253D&md5=71a192450daca2ead39d26fb0abdcfec
          open URL
        87. 87
          Berger, P.; Kim, M. Polymer Solar Cells: P3HT:PCBM and Beyond. J. Renewable Sustainable Energy 2018, 10, 013508  DOI: 10.1063/1.5012992
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          87
          Polymer solar cells: P3HT:PCBM and beyond
          Berger, P. R.; Kim, M.
          Journal of Renewable and Sustainable Energy (2018), 10 (1), 013508/1-013508/26CODEN: JRSEBH; ISSN:1941-7012. (American Institute of Physics)
          A review. For the last two decades, polymer solar cells (PSCs) have been a cynosure of the photovoltaic community, as evidenced by the growing no. of patent applications and scientific publications. Efforts to achieve high power conversion efficiency in PSC, propelled by advances in device architecture, material combination, and nanomorphol. control, evolved into poly(3-hexylthiophene-2,5-diyl) (P3HT):phenyl-C61-Butyric-Acid-Me Ester (PCBM) bulk heterojunction PSCs, which had been the best seller in PSC research for a decade. Subsequently, PSC research was redirected towards the synthesis of low bandgap materials and optimization of tandem cells, which led to a power conversion efficiency of ∼13%. Even though this efficiency may not be sufficient enough to compete with that of inorg. solar cells, unique properties of PSCs, such as mass roll-to-roll prodn. capability, as well as flexibility and lightness, suggest their niche market opportunities. In this review, an overview of developments in PSCs is presented during the last three decades encompassing pre- and post-P3HT:PCBM era. Emphasis is given on evolution in device architecture, coupled with material selection for pre-P3HT:PCBM era, and synthesis of low-bandgap materials, coupled with a tandem structure for post-P3HT:PCBM era. Last but not least, efforts toward the longer operational lifetime of PSCs by encapsulation are reviewed. (c) 2018 American Institute of Physics.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXjtFKqs7Y%253D&md5=1acb5d5c795afebcf04ebf9e57f7ff82
          open URL
        88. 88
          Tremel, K.; Ludwigs, S. P3HT Revisited-From Molecular Scale to Solar Cell Devices; Springer, 2014; Vol. 265.
          Google Scholar
          There is no corresponding record for this reference.
          open URL
        89. 89
          Manna, A. K.; Balamurugan, D.; Cheung, M. S.; Dunietz, B. D. Unraveling the Mechanism of Photoinduced Charge Transfer in Carotenoid–Porphyrin–C60 Molecular Triad. J. Phys. Chem. Lett. 2015, 6, 1231– 1237,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpclett.5b00074
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          89
          Unraveling the Mechanism of Photoinduced Charge Transfer in Carotenoid-Porphyrin-C60 Molecular Triad
          Manna, Arun K.; Balamurugan, D.; Cheung, Margaret S.; Dunietz, Barry D.
          Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters (2015), 6 (7), 1231-1237CODEN: JPCLCD; ISSN:1948-7185. (American Chemical Society)
          Photoinduced charge transfer (CT) plays a central role in biol. significant systems and in applications that harvest solar energy. The authors study the relation of CT kinetics and conformation in a mol. triad. The triad, consisting of carotenoid, porphyrin, and fullerene is structurally flexible and able to acquire significantly varied conformations under ambient conditions. With an integrated approach of quantum calcns. and mol. dynamics simulations, the authors compute the rate of CT at two distinctive conformations. The linearly extended conformation, in which the donor (carotenoid) and the acceptor (fullerene) are sepd. by nearly 50 Å, enables charge sepn. through a sequential CT process. A representative bent conformation that is entropically dominant, however, attenuates the CT, although the donor and the acceptor are spatially closer. The computed rate of CT at the linear conformation is in good agreement with measured values. The work provides unique fundamental understanding of the photoinduced CT process in the mol. triad.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXksFSktb0%253D&md5=71e57ade98c20f3318d0fd0866f5cdfd
          open URL
        90. 90
          Gmucová, K.; Nádazzdy, V.; Schauer, F.; Kaiser, M.; Majková, E. Electrochemical Spectroscopic Methods for the Fine Band Gap Electronic Structure Mapping in Organic Semiconductors. J. Phys. Chem. C 2015, 119, 15926– 15934,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpcc.5b04378
          [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
          90
          Electrochemical Spectroscopic Methods for the Fine Band Gap Electronic Structure Mapping in Organic Semiconductors
          Gmucova, Katarina; Nadazdy, Vojtech; Schauer, Frantisek; Kaiser, Michal; Majkova, Eva
          Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2015), 119 (28), 15926-15934CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
          Functionality of org. photonic devices is markedly influenced by the electronic band structure of the used materials. An easy and quick detn. of the d. of states function (DOS) in the whole energy range from HOMO to LUMO, including the presence of defect states in the band gap, is a prerequisite to a successful design of photonic devices. The authors present the fine band gap electronic structure mapping in P3HT with two electrochem. spectroscopic methods: the energy-resolved electrochem. impedance spectroscopy (ER-EIS) and the kinetic sensitive voltcoulometry (VCM). The P3HT exposition to air results in the change of light-induced polaron states in the band gap. The electrochem. measured data are compared with those from the literature, obtained with combined optical spectroscopic methods, elec. methods, or 1st-principles calcns. The ER-EIS method was shown as capable of providing valuable information on the DOS in the whole energy range from HOMO to LUMO, and the VCM method opens the possibility to study sep. the charge transfer (redox) processes with different kinetics.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtVarsrjK&md5=c5e54094e46ac68336e0257ac563c02f
          open URL
        91. 91
          Kroon, R.; Lenes, M.; Hummelen, J. C.; Blom, P. W.; De Boer, B. Small bandgap Polymers for Organic Solar Cells (Polymer Material Development in the Last 5 Years). Polym. Rev. 2008, 48, 531– 582,  DOI: 10.1080/15583720802231833
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          91
          Small Bandgap Polymers for Organic Solar Cells (Polymer Material Development in the Last 5 Years)
          Kroon, Renee; Lenes, Martijn; Hummelen, Jan C.; Blom, Paul W. M.; de Boer, Bert
          Polymer Reviews (Philadelphia, PA, United States) (2008), 48 (3), 531-582CODEN: PRPPCY; ISSN:1558-3724. (Taylor & Francis, Inc.)
          A review on recent developments of small band gap (<2.0 eV) polymer materials for photovoltaic applications. First, an introduction is given regarding the processes governing the exciton dissocn., charge transport requirements, energy level engineering of both donor and acceptor materials, and other parameters detg. the photovoltaic performance. The focus is on polymeric donor materials, which are subdivided by the type of monomeric units that constitute the backbone. The synthetic methods and conditions, processing of the devices, and the device performances are summarized. To enhance efficiencies further, research activities for new materials are needed with better aligned energy levels. One interesting approach is by narrowing the donor bandgap to enhance light absorption.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXps1Smsbk%253D&md5=de7abfba526fe0e618c3964a44349356
          open URL
        92. 92
          Kar, S.; Roy, J. K.; Leszczynski, J. In silico designing of power conversion efficient organic lead dyes for solar cells using todays innovative approaches to assure renewable energy for future. NPJ Comput. Mater. 2017, 3, 22  DOI: 10.1038/s41524-017-0025-z
          [Crossref], Google Scholar
          There is no corresponding record for this reference.
          open URL
        93. 93
          Lopez, S. A.; Sanchez-Lengeling, B.; de Goes Soares, J.; Aspuru-Guzik, A. Design principles and top non-fullerene acceptor candidates for organic photovoltaics. Joule 2017, 1, 857– 870,  DOI: 10.1016/j.joule.2017.10.006
          [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
          93
          Design Principles and Top Non-Fullerene Acceptor Candidates for Organic Photovoltaics
          Lopez, Steven A.; Sanchez-Lengeling, Benjamin; Soares, Julio de Goes; Aspuru-Guzik, Alan
          Joule (2017), 1 (4), 857-870CODEN: JOULBR; ISSN:2542-4351. (Cell Press)
          Non-fullerene acceptors in org. photovoltaics (OPVs) continue to improve upon the shortcomings of many fullerene-based solar cells. We explored the chem. space of over 51,000 non-fullerene acceptors featuring 106 common moieties from the org. electronics literature, including naphthalene diimides, benzathiadiazoles, and fused fluoroanthenediimides. We identify top candidates featuring optimal energy level offsets, based on a well-studied electron-donor: poly[N-9'-heptadecanyl-2,7-carbazole-alt-5,5-(4',7'-di-2-thienyl-2',1',3'-benzothiadiazole)]. The Harvard Clean Energy Project infrastructure was employed through the IBM World Community Grid to carry out quantum mech. calcns. using d. functional theory. Gaussian processes regression was utilized to correct the computed frontier MO energies. Addnl. time-dependent d. functional theory calcns. on a subset of the top candidates refined the narrow band-gap chromophores for OPVs. These results on electron-acceptor materials complement the electronic structure calcns. of over one million electron-donor materials publicly available through our website.
          >> More from SciFinder ®
          https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXpvFGhu7o%253D&md5=86b5c57cc28040130f7e03673d4122f1
          open URL
        94. 94
          NREL N R E L Best Research-Cell Efficiency Chart 2019. https://www.nrel.gov/pv/cell-efficiency.html, 2019.
          Google Scholar
          There is no corresponding record for this reference.
